source_title: TESK Rehabilitation Kit (TRK) 2025
target_name: Set 2: Includes consumable supplies that are not assistive products but are needed to support an acute trauma rehabilitation service.

source_title: TESK Rehabilitation Kit (TRK) 2025
target_name: The set includes stump bandaging, tubular and compression bandaging, exercise bands, supplies for making basic bespoke splints with plaster of paris, which should only be undertaken by appropriately trained staff.

source_title: TESK Rehabilitation Kit (TRK) 2025
target_name: Set 3: Includes basic off the shelf wrist sprints and orthoses, in a range of sizes, predominantly for patients with peripheral nerve injury, but may also be used to maintain wrist or ankle positioning or provide protection in other patients.

source_title: TESK Rehabilitation Kit (TRK) 2025
target_name: Set 4: Includes non-consumable equipment for patient assessment, including stethoscope, oximeter, and goniometer . for 1 professional (or shared between 2-3).

source_title: TESK Rehabilitation Kit (TRK) 2025
target_name: Repeat orders are not required unless staff numbers increase or items are lost.

source_title: TESK Rehabilitation Kit (TRK) 2025
target_name: This set also includes consumables for respiratory interventions - including incentive spirometers (single patient use) and suction tubing to make bubble PEP, that are not anticipated to be needed in significant quantities.

source_title: TESK Rehabilitation Kit (TRK) 2025
target_name: Set 5: Includes static (foam) pressure reducing mattresses that can be used to support a surge in complex inpatient cases or provided to patients with long term injuries to use at home.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Rehabilitation helps a child, adult or older person to be as independent as possible in everyday activities and enables participation in education, work, recreation and meaningful life roles such as taking care of family.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Globally, an estimated 2.4 billion people are currently living with a health condition that may benefit from rehabilitation.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: The need for rehabilitation worldwide is predicted to increase due to changes in the health and characteristics of the population.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Rehabilitation is an important part of universal health coverage and is a key strategy for achieving Sustainable Development Goal 3 . “Ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages”.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Overview Rehabilitation is defined as “a set of interventions designed to optimize functioning and reduce disability in individuals with health conditions in interaction with their environment”.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Put simply, rehabilitation helps a child, adult or older person to be as independent as possible in everyday activities and enables participation in education, work, recreation and meaningful life roles such as taking care of family.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Together, these strategies can help an individual; overcome difficulties with thinking, seeing, hearing, communicating, eating or moving around.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: speech and language training to improve a person’s communication after a brain injury

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: physical exercise training to improve muscle strength, voluntary movements and balance in persons with stroke or Parkinson disease

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: modifying an older person’s home environment to improve their safety and independence at home and to reduce their risk of falls

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: positioning and splinting techniques to assist with skin healing, reduce swelling, and to regain movement after burn surgery

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: prescribing medicine to reduce spasticity for a child with cerebral palsy

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: and working with a patient in intensive care to improve their breathing, prevent complications and speed their recovery after critical illness Rehabilitation is highly person-centred, meaning that the interventions selected for each individual are targeted to their goals and preferences.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: The benefits of rehabilitation Rehabilitation can reduce the impact of a broad range of health conditions, including diseases (acute or chronic), illnesses or injuries.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: It complements other health interventions, such as medical and surgical interventions, helping to facilitate recovery and achieve the best outcome possible.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: In addition, rehabilitation can help to prevent, reduce or manage complications associated with many health conditions, such as in the context of spinal cord injury, stroke, or fractures.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Rehabilitation helps to minimize or slow down the disabling effects of chronic health conditions, such as cardiovascular disease, cancer and diabetes by equipping people with self-management strategies and the assistive products they require, or by addressing pain or other complications.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Rehabilitation is an investment, with cost benefits for both the individuals and society.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: It can help to avoid costly hospitalization, reduce hospital length of stay, and prevent re-admissions.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: For the full extent of the social, economic and health benefits of rehabilitation to be realized, timely, high quality and affordable rehabilitation interventions should be available to all.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Unmet global need for rehabilitation Globally, about 2.4 billion people are currently living with a health condition that may benefit from rehabilitation.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: With changes taking place in the health and characteristics of the population worldwide, this estimated need for rehabilitation is only going to increase in the coming years.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: These health conditions can impact an individual’s functioning and are linked to increased levels of disability, for which rehabilitation can be beneficial. In many parts of the world, this increasing need for rehabilitation is going largely unmet.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: The result is that pre-existing limitations in rehabilitation services are magnified, health service delivery is less efficient, and people directly affected are at risk of increased impairment and disability.

target_name: They also simultaneously disrupt existing services and have the greatest impact on the most vulnerable populations and the weakest health systems. target_name: Overview Rehabilitation is defined as “a set of interventions designed to optimize functioning and reduce disability in individuals with health conditions in interaction with their environment”.

target_name: Rehabilitation can be provided in many different places, such as inpatient or outpatient hospital settings, outpatient physio- or occupational therapy practices, and community settings such as an individual’s home, a school or a workplace.

target_name: and working with a patient in intensive care to improve their breathing, prevent complications and speed their recovery after critical illness Rehabilitation is highly person-centred, meaning that the interventions selected for each individual are targeted to their goals and preferences.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: In addition, rehabilitation can help to prevent, reduce or manage complications associated with many health conditions, such as in the context of spinal cord injury, stroke, or fractures.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Rehabilitation helps to minimize or slow down the disabling effects of chronic health conditions, such as cardiovascular disease, cancer and diabetes by equipping people with self-management strategies and the assistive products they require, or by addressing pain or other complications.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: It can help to avoid costly hospitalization, reduce hospital length of stay, and prevent re-admissions.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: Rehabilitation in emergencies Natural hazards such as earthquakes or disease outbreaks and human induced hazards including conflict, terrorism or industrial accidents can generate overwhelming rehabilitation needs as a result of injury or illness.

source_title: Rehabilitation
target_name: The result is that pre-existing limitations in rehabilitation services are magnified, health service delivery is less efficient, and people directly affected are at risk of increased impairment and disability.

target_name: Globally, an estimated 2.4 billion people are currently living with a health condition that may benefit from rehabilitation.

source_title: Effect of Physiotherapy Interventions on Motor Symptoms in People With Parkinson's Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta‑Analysis
target_name: PMID: 37070664 DOI: 10.1177/10998004231171587 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of different types of physiotherapy interventions in people with Parkinson's disease (PD).

source_title: Effect of Physiotherapy Interventions on Motor Symptoms in People With Parkinson's Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta‑Analysis
target_name: Across all types of physiotherapy, strength training, mind-body exercise, aerobic exercise, and non-invasive brain stimulation (NiBS) were effective in improving motor symptoms as measured by the (Movement Disorders Society-) Unified PD Scale, whereas balance and gait training (BGT) and acupuncture were not.

source_title: Effect of Physiotherapy Interventions on Motor Symptoms in People With Parkinson's Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta‑Analysis
target_name: The pooled results showed that the change in mind-body exercise (MD = -5.36, 95% CI [-7.97 to -2.74], p < .01, I 2 = 68%) and NiBS (MD = -4.59, 95% CI [-8.59 to -0.59], p = .02, I 2 = 78%) reached clinical threshold, indicating clinically meaningful improvements.

source_title: Effect of Physiotherapy Interventions on Motor Symptoms in People With Parkinson's Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta‑Analysis
target_name: Considering the effectiveness of the interventions on motor symptoms, balance, gait and functional mobility, mind-body exercise was recommended the most.

source_title: Effect of Physiotherapy Interventions on Motor Symptoms in People With Parkinson's Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta‑Analysis
target_name: Conclusions: Exercise appears to be a better form of physiotherapy than NiBS and acupuncture for improving motor function.

source_title: Effect of Physiotherapy Interventions on Motor Symptoms in People With Parkinson's Disease: A Systematic Review and Meta‑Analysis
target_name: Mind-body exercise showed beneficial effects on motor symptoms, balance, gait and functional mobility in people with PD, and is worthy of being promoted.

source_title: Current interventional model for movement in Parkinson's disease: network meta‑analysis based on the improvement of motor ability
target_name: To identify optimally therapeutic exercise interventions for improving motor ability among patients with Parkinson's disease (PD), we conducted a network meta-analysis (NMA) of randomized controlled trials comparing different exercise regimens.

source_title: Current interventional model for movement in Parkinson's disease: network meta‑analysis based on the improvement of motor ability
target_name: Exercise outcomes as measured by Movement Disorder Society- Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale Part III (MDS-UPDRS-III) score change were evaluated and ranked using STATA software version 18.0.

source_title: Current interventional model for movement in Parkinson's disease: network meta‑analysis based on the improvement of motor ability
target_name: Although most exercise interventions showed some efficacy (reducing MDS-UPDRS-III score), cumulative ranking probability surface (SUCRA) values indicated that the best exercise interventions for motor function improvement were archery (95.6%), riding a bicycle (80.9%), and binary rhythm dance (80.8%).

source_title: Current interventional model for movement in Parkinson's disease: network meta‑analysis based on the improvement of motor ability
target_name: Conclusion: An exercise intervention comprising archery, cycling, and(or) binary rhythm dance may yield superior improvements in motor function among patients with Parkinson's disease.

target_name: PMID: 34997759 DOI: 10.1111/ane.13579 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract In 2015, Uhrbrand et al. published the first review on Parkinson´s disease (PD) and exercise entirely based on randomized controlled trials (RCT) applying strict exercise definitions.

source_title: Parkinson's disease and intensive exercise therapy – systematic review & meta‑analysis
target_name: The present review aimed to update the PD literature by assessing the effects of different intensive exercise modalities: resistance training (RT), endurance training (ET), and other intensive exercise modalities (OITM).

source_title: Parkinson's disease and intensive exercise therapy – systematic review & meta‑analysis
target_name: RT, ET, and OITM were feasible, safe, and did not worsen PD symptoms. Furthermore, RT, ET, and OITM may positively affect functional outcomes (e.g., balance) and depressive symptoms in PD but inconsistencies across these findings warrant cautious conclusions.

source_title: Parkinson's disease and intensive exercise therapy – systematic review & meta‑analysis
target_name: In conclusion, RT, ET, and OITM all represent safe, feasible, and beneficial adjunct rehabilitation strategies in PD, with particularly RT and ET showing solid effects.

source_title: Parkinson's disease and intensive exercise therapy – systematic review & meta‑analysis
target_name: The present review aimed to update the PD literature by assessing the effects of different intensive exercise modalities: resistance training (RT), endurance training (ET), and other intensive exercise modalities (OITM).

source_title: Parkinson's disease and intensive exercise therapy – systematic review & meta‑analysis
target_name: RT, ET, and OITM were feasible, safe, and did not worsen PD symptoms. Furthermore, RT, ET, and OITM may positively affect functional outcomes (e.g., balance) and depressive symptoms in PD but inconsistencies across these findings warrant cautious conclusions.

source_title: Parkinson's disease and intensive exercise therapy – systematic review & meta‑analysis
target_name: Meta-analyses showed that RT had a positive impact on muscle strength (standardized mean difference (SMD) = 0.83 [95% CI;0.54, 1.12]), functional capacity (Timed Up and Go Test (TUG)

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: PMID: 32917125 PMCID: PMC7564288 DOI: 10.1177/1545968320952799 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract Background: Physiotherapy is a commonly prescribed intervention for people with Parkinson's disease (PD).

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Conventional types of physiotherapy have been studied extensively, while novel modalities are being developed and evaluated.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of conventional and more recent physiotherapy interventions for people with PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: The meta-analysis performed as part of the 2014 European Physiotherapy Guideline for PD was used as the starting point and updated with the latest evidence.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Randomized controlled trials comparing any physiotherapy intervention with no intervention or sham treatment were included.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Trials were classified into 12 categories: conventional physiotherapy, resistance training, treadmill training, strategy training, dance, martial arts, aerobic exercises, hydrotherapy, balance and gait training, dual tasking, exergaming, and Nordic walking.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Conventional physiotherapy significantly improved motor symptoms, gait, and quality of life.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Resistance training improved gait.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Treadmill training improved gait.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Strategy training improved balance and gait.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Dance, Nordic walking, balance and gait training, and martial arts improved motor symptoms, balance, and gait.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Hydrotherapy improved balance.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Finally, dual task training did not significantly improve any of the outcomes studied.

source_title: Physiotherapy in Parkinson's Disease: A Meta‑Analysis of Present Treatment Modalities
target_name: Conclusions: This meta-analysis provides a comprehensive overview of the evidence for the effectiveness of different physiotherapy interventions in the management of PD, allowing clinicians and patients to make an evidence-based decision for specific treatment modalities.

source_title: Effect of Long‑term Exercise Therapy on Motor Symptoms in Parkinson Disease Patients – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: The aims of the study were to assess the effectiveness of long-term exercise therapy (≥12 wks) for patients with Parkinson disease and to derive specific suggestions on how the motor symptom improvements can be optimized by exercise type and exercise dose.

source_title: Effect of Long‑term Exercise Therapy on Motor Symptoms in Parkinson Disease Patients – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Design: The PubMed, Web of Science, Cochrane Central Register, Embase, Scopus, and CNKI databases were searched up to January 2021 for randomized controlled trials focusing on the effects of long-term exercise for Parkinson disease.

source_title: Effect of Long‑term Exercise Therapy on Motor Symptoms in Parkinson Disease Patients – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Results: Tai Chi, resistance training, and dance provide significant improvements in physical function and functional mobility.

source_title: Effect of Long‑term Exercise Therapy on Motor Symptoms in Parkinson Disease Patients – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: However, walking capacity outcomes did not improve after Tai Chi and resistance training but did improve after dance.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Authors Andreas Wallin 1 , Erika Franzén 2 , Jakob Studsgaard 3 , Mikkel Baltzer Hansen 4 , Sverker Johansson 5 , John Kodal Brincks 6 Affiliations 1 Department of Neurobiology, Care Sciences and Society, Division of Physiotherapy, Karolinska Institutet, Huddinge, Sweden

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: PMID: 39915205 DOI: 10.1016/j.parkreldis.2025.107310 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract Background: Rehabilitation in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) often includes balance training, but knowledge about optimal training content remains limited.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Objectives: To describe the design, content, delivery, and reporting of balance training for individuals with PD, and furthermore, to map the systematic use and reporting of methods monitoring intensity in balance training interventions for individuals with PD.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Interventions with at least 50 % of exercises challenging balance control were included.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Balance training types (exergaming, multi-modal, sensory-motor integrated, and task-oriented) were categorized based on specific balance exercise components

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Training Frequency, Intensity, Time, Type, Volume, and Progression (FITT-VP principles) were extracted.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Intensity strategies were reported in 93 % of the exergaming interventions, which was superior to the other training types (multi-modal (18 %), sensory-motor (17 %), and task-oriented (6 %)).

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Conclusions: Multi-modal and sensory-motor interventions had a greater focus on challenging balance components compared to other types of training, while exergaming interventions demonstrated superior reporting of intensity strategies.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Future research is encouraged to prioritize implementing intensity strategies and aim to incorporate a broader range of balance components within balance training exercises.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Keywords: Parkinson's disease; Physiotherapy; Systematic review; balance control; balance training.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Objectives: To describe the design, content, delivery, and reporting of balance training for individuals with PD, and furthermore, to map the systematic use and reporting of methods monitoring intensity in balance training interventions for individuals with PD.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Training Frequency, Intensity, Time, Type, Volume, and Progression (FITT-VP principles) were extracted.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Results: In total, 114 studies (interventions n = 126) with 5335 participants (mean age: 67.5 years; mean PD duration: 6.8 years) were included.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Intensity strategies were reported in 93 % of the exergaming interventions, which was superior to the other training types (multi-modal (18 %), sensory-motor (17 %), and task-oriented (6 %)).

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Conclusions: Multi-modal and sensory-motor interventions had a greater focus on challenging balance components compared to other types of training, while exergaming interventions demonstrated superior reporting of intensity strategies.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Objectives: To describe the design, content, delivery, and reporting of balance training for individuals with PD, and furthermore, to map the systematic use and reporting of methods monitoring intensity in balance training interventions for individuals with PD.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Interventions with at least 50 % of exercises challenging balance control were included.

target_name: Balance training types (exergaming, multi-modal, sensory-motor integrated, and task-oriented) were categorized based on specific balance exercise components

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: motor (limits of stability, anticipatory motor strategies, reactive motor strategies, and control of dynamics), sensory (vestibular, visual, and somatosensory systems), and cognitive (dual-tasking in motor or cognitive activities).

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: The highest mean number of balance components was found in the multi-modal (5.8), followed by sensory-motor (5.6), task-oriented (4.2), and exergaming (4.0).

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Conclusions: Multi-modal and sensory-motor interventions had a greater focus on challenging balance components compared to other types of training, while exergaming interventions demonstrated superior reporting of intensity strategies.

source_title: Balance exercise interventions in Parkinson's disease – systematic mapping review
target_name: Future research is encouraged to prioritize implementing intensity strategies and aim to incorporate a broader range of balance components within balance training exercises.

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: Objectives: To compare the effects of different types of physical exercise in adults with PD on the severity of motor signs, quality of life (QoL), and the occurrence of adverse events, and to generate a clinically meaningful treatment ranking using network meta-analyses (NMAs).

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: Selection criteria: We included randomized controlled trials (RCTs) comparing one type of physical exercise for adults with PD to another type of exercise, a control group, or both.

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: We categorized the interventions and analyzed their effects on the severity of motor signs, QoL, freezing of gait, and functional mobility and balance up to six weeks after the intervention using NMAs.

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: We observed evidence of beneficial effects for most types of physical exercise included in our review compared to a passive control group.

target_name: Authors' conclusions: We found evidence of beneficial effects on the severity of motor signs and QoL for most types of physical exercise for people with PD included in this review, but little evidence of differences between these interventions.

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: Thus, our review highlights the importance of physical exercise regarding our primary outcomes severity of motor signs and QoL, while the exact exercise type might be secondary.

target_name: Notably, this conclusion is consistent with the possibility that specific motor symptoms may be treated most effectively by PD-specific programs. Although the evidence is very uncertain about the effect of exercise on the risk of adverse events, the interventions included in our review were described as relatively safe.

target_name: Objectives: To compare the effects of different types of physical exercise in adults with PD on the severity of motor signs, quality of life (QoL), and the occurrence of adverse events, and to generate a clinically meaningful treatment ranking using network meta-analyses (NMAs).

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: Two review authors independently assessed the risk of bias using the risk of bias 2 (RoB 2) tool and rated the confidence in the evidence using the CINeMA approach for results on the severity of motor signs and QoL.

target_name: Due to heterogeneous reporting of adverse events, we summarized safety data narratively and rated our confidence in the evidence using the GRADE approach.

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: Adverse events Only 85 studies (5192 participants) provided some kind of safety data, mostly only for the intervention groups.

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: No adverse events (AEs) occurred in 40 studies and no serious AEs occurred in four studies.

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: The evidence is very uncertain about the effect of physical exercise on the risk of adverse events (very low confidence).

source_title: Physical exercise for people with Parkinson's disease – systematic review & network meta‑analysis
target_name: Notably, this conclusion is consistent with the possibility that specific motor symptoms may be treated most effectively by PD-specific programs. Although the evidence is very uncertain about the effect of exercise on the risk of adverse events, the interventions included in our review were described as relatively safe.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: PMID: 38335243 DOI: 10.1093/ptj/pzae014 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract Objective: Parkinson disease (PD) is associated with a predictable decline in motor function and mobility that is commonly managed with exercise.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: There is a limited understanding of the effects of group exercise compared to individual exercise (IE) and usual care (UC) on motor function and mobility.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Our purpose was to investigate the effects of group exercise compared to IE and UC on motor function and mobility for people with PD.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed with randomized control trials that investigated the effects of group compared with IE and UC on motor function and mobility for people with PD.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Results: Twenty-three studies assessed at least 1 mobility-related outcome measure, met our inclusion criteria, and were included in quantitative analysis.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: There was no significant difference on motor function and mobility between group exercise and IE for all standardized outcome assessment meta-analyses.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Motor function and mobility were significantly improved with group exercise compared to UC in 9 of 11 standardized outcome assessment meta-analyses.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Conclusion: Based upon low to moderate quality of evidence, group exercise has a similar to larger effect as IE and UC on improving motor function and mobility for people with PD.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: When used in combination with skilled physical therapy, group exercise may be an appropriate adjunct to individualized physical therapy to maximize mobility and function.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Impact: Long-term adherence to exercise is essential to maintain mobility and motor function for people with PD.

source_title: Effects of Group Exercise on Motor Function and Mobility for Parkinson Disease – Systematic Review & Meta‑analysis
target_name: Our study suggests group exercise is as effective as IE and may be an appropriate option to encourage long-term adherence related to increased access, socialization, and accountability.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Abstract Introduction: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor and non-motor symptoms. While incurable, exercise has shown therapeutic benefits.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Stretching, an accessible and low-cost modality, may improve mobility, balance, and flexibility, warranting systematic evaluation for managing PD symptoms. This systematic review aimed to examine and critically analyze scientific evidence on the effects of stretching in people with Parkinson's disease.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Stretching programs lasted 4 weeks to 6 months.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Positive effects were observed in motor symptoms and functional mobility for people with PD, although these were generally less pronounced compared to interventions like Tai Chi or WuQinXi Qigong.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Conclusion: Stretching improves motor symptoms and mobility in people with PD, but its benefits for gait, motor function, and mental health are limited compared to other exercises.

This systematic review aimed to examine and critically analyze scientific evidence on the effects of stretching in people with Parkinson's disease.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Methods: A search was conducted in four electronic databases (Scopus, Web of Science, PEDro, and MEDLINE/PubMed) from inception to November 2024.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Results: Twelve randomized controlled trials were analyzed.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Positive effects were observed in motor symptoms and functional mobility for people with PD, although these were generally less pronounced compared to interventions like Tai Chi or WuQinXi Qigong.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: In contrast, mixed results to no significant improvements were observed for balance, gait, strength, cardiorespiratory fitness, mental health, neurocognitive function, sleep quality, physical activity levels, and fatigue.

source_title: The effects of stretching in Parkinson's disease – systematic review of RCTs
target_name: Conclusion: Stretching improves motor symptoms and mobility in people with PD, but its benefits for gait, motor function, and mental health are limited compared to other exercises.

source_title: Exercise and training‑based interventions for freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease – systematic review
target_name: Exercise and training are therefore advocated as important adjunct therapies.

source_title: Exercise and training‑based interventions for freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease – systematic review
target_name: In this meta-analysis, we assess the existing evidence for such interventions to reduce FOG, and further examine which type of training helps the restoration of gait function in particular.

source_title: Exercise and training‑based interventions for freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease – systematic review
target_name: The primary meta-analysis across 41 studies and 1838 patients revealed a favorable moderate effect size (ES = -0.37) of various training modalities for reducing subjective FOG-severity (p < 0.00001), though several interventions were not directly aimed at FOG and some included non-freezers.

source_title: Exercise and training‑based interventions for freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease – systematic review
target_name: However, exercise and training also proved beneficial in a secondary analysis on freezers only (ES = -0.32, p = 0.007).

source_title: Exercise and training‑based interventions for freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease – systematic review
target_name: We further revealed that dedicated training aimed at reducing FOG episodes (ES = -0.24) or ameliorating the underlying correlates of FOG (ES = -0.40) was moderately effective (p < 0.01), while generic exercises were not (ES = -0.14, p = 0.12).

source_title: Exercise and training‑based interventions for freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease – systematic review
target_name: Relevantly, no retention effects were seen after cessation of training (ES = -0.08, p = 0.36).

source_title: Exercise and training‑based interventions for freezing of gait in Parkinson's disease – systematic review
target_name: This review thereby supports the implementation of targeted training as a treatment for FOG with the need for long-term engagement. © 2021.

source_title: Exercise as medicine in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Authors Martin Langeskov-Christensen 1 2 , Erika Franzén 3 4 , Lars Grøndahl Hvid 5 6 , Ulrik Dalgas 5 Affiliations 1 Exercise Biology, Department of Public Health, Aarhus University, Aarhus, Denmark mach@clin.au.dk.

source_title: Exercise as medicine in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Identification of interventions that prevent, slow, halt or mitigate the disease is therefore pivotal. Exercise is safe and represents a cornerstone in PD rehabilitation, but exercise may have even more fundamental benefits that could change clinical practice.

source_title: Exercise as medicine in Parkinson's disease
target_name: In PD, the existing knowledge base supports exercise as (1) a protective lifestyle factor preventing the disease (ie, primary prevention), (2) a potential disease-modifying therapy (ie, secondary prevention) and (3) an effective symptomatic treatment (ie, tertiary prevention).

source_title: Exercise as medicine in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Based on current evidence, a paradigm shift is proposed, stating that exercise should be individually prescribed as medicine to persons with PD at an early disease stage, alongside conventional medical treatment.

source_title: Systematic review to inform WHO guideline: Structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain
target_name: Evaluate benefits and harms of structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain (CPLBP) in adults to inform a World Health Organization (WHO) standard clinical guideline.

source_title: Systematic review to inform WHO guideline: Structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain
target_name: Eligible RCTs targeted structured exercise programs compared to placebo/sham, usual care, or no intervention (including comparison interventions where the attributable effect of exercise could be isolated).

source_title: Systematic review to inform WHO guideline: Structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain
target_name: Assessing individual exercise types (predominantly very low certainty evidence), pain reduction was associated with aerobic exercise and Pilates vs. no intervention, and motor control exercise vs. sham.

source_title: Systematic review to inform WHO guideline: Structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain
target_name: Improved function was associated with mixed exercise vs. usual care, and Pilates vs. no intervention.

source_title: Systematic review to inform WHO guideline: Structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain
target_name: Temporary increased minor pain was associated with mixed exercise vs. no intervention, and yoga vs. usual care.

source_title: Systematic review to inform WHO guideline: Structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain
target_name: When pooling exercise types, exercise vs. no intervention probably reduces pain in adults (8 RCTs, SMD = - 0.33, 95% CI - 0.58 to - 0.08) and functional limitations in adults and older adults (8 RCTs, SMD = - 0.31, 95% CI - 0.57 to - 0.05) (moderate certainty evidence).

source_title: Systematic review to inform WHO guideline: Structured exercise programs for chronic primary low back pain
target_name: Conclusions: With moderate certainty, structured exercise programs probably reduce pain and functional limitations in adults and older people with CPLBP.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Keywords: Clinical, Clinical Guidelines, Decision-Making, Parkinson Disease Introduction Overview This clinical practice guideline (CPG) is based on a systematic review of published studies involving the physical therapist management of individuals with Parkinson disease (PD).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In addition to providing practice recommendations (see Tab.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Current evidence-based practice standards demand that clinicians use the best available evidence in their clinical decision-making, incorporate clinical expertise, and consider the individual’s wants and needs.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Recommendations guide evidence-based practice while considering the individual’s wants and needs in the clinical decision-making process.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Physical therapists are health care professionals who help individuals maintain, restore, and improve movement, activity, and functioning to enable optimal performance and enhance health, well-being, and quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Neurologists, adult primary care clinicians, geriatricians, rehabilitation medicine provider, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, and other health care professionals who routinely see individuals with PD in various practice settings also may benefit from this guideline.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Care for individuals with PD is based on decisions made by them in consultation with their health care team, which may comprise movement disorder specialists, general neurologists, geriatricians, primary care physicians, nurses, physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, registered dieticians, social workers, and other professionals.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Methods from the American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) Clinical Practice Guideline Manual 13 and the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS) Clinical Practice Guideline Methodology 14 were used in development of this CPG.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: This CPG was prepared by the APTA Parkinson Disease Clinical Practice Guideline Development Group (clinical experts) with the assistance of the AAOS Clinical Quality and Value Department (methodologists).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The GDG performed final reviews of the literature and created the recommendations, provided rationale in the context of physical therapist practice, and adjusted the strength of the recommendations depending on the magnitude of benefit, risk, harm, and cost.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Best Practice ♦ ◊◊◊ Recommended practice based on current clinical practice norms; exceptional situations in which validating studies have not or cannot be performed yet there is a clear benefit, harm, or cost; or expert opinion.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The reviewer provided important feedback on the draft from the perspective of a physical therapy user and commented on the clarity and feasibility of implementing the recommendations.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The large number of outcome measures utilized could contribute to unwanted variation in practice and led to challenges when determining the effect size of a particular intervention.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The Academy of Neurologic Physical Therapy developed outcome measures in the Parkinson Evidence Database to Guide Effectiveness (PDEDGE).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Role of the Funding Source The American Physical Therapy Association, which funded the travel for 1 GDG meeting and for the AAOS services, provided coordination but played no other role in the design and conduct of this CPG or in the reporting of the recommendations.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Commenters consisted of the APTA Board of Directors (Board), the APTA Scientific and Practice Affairs Committee, all relevant APTA sections and academies, stakeholder organizations, and the physical therapy community at large.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Recommendations Aerobic Exercise ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapists should implement moderate- to high-intensity aerobic exercise to improve oxygen consumption (VO 2 ), reduce motor disease severity, and improve functional outcomes in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 33 Rationale Nine high-quality and 7 moderate-quality studies examined the benefits of aerobic exercise in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Exercise studies encompassed in this section included an aerobic component, spanning moderate to high intensity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Across most studies, moderate-intensity exercise was defined as 60% to 75% of maximum heart rate (HR), whereas high-intensity exercise was defined as 75% to 85% of maximum HR.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 21 , 23 , 24 However, there was variability in how moderate-exercise and high-intensity exercise were defined to determine target HR.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 18 , 30 Furthermore, some studies encompassed aerobic exercise that started at moderate intensity and gradually increased to high intensity , 26 , 31 whereas other studies defined target intensities that spanned the moderate to high ranges.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 22 These studies also varied considerably in sample size, comparison group, outcomes measured, mode, and dose of aerobic exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: VO 2 and motor disease severity Improvements at the impairment level have been demonstrated in many aerobic exercise trials in PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: High- 24 , 26 and moderate-quality 29 , 30 , 32 studies found that aerobic exercise compared with control (eg, usual care, stretching, strengthening) improved VO 2 , suggesting a specificity of training effect.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Though the effect of aerobic training on motor signs was mixed, 4 high-quality studies 22.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 24 , 26 revealed significantly reduced motor decline as measured by the Movement Disorders Society Unified Parkinson Disease Rating Scale part III motor examination .

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 34 , 35 Two of the high-quality aerobic exercise trials with the largest sample sizes 24 , 26 found less motor decline compared with a control condition (eg, usual care, stretching) in those with de novo PD or early PD (H&Y stages 1 to 2) tested in the “off” state.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: It has been suggested that dopaminergic replacement medications may mask the benefits of exercise, thus potentially accounting for lack of effects of aerobic exercise on motor symptoms when measured in the “on” state.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Few studies have examined the effects of aerobic exercise on nonmotor signs; however, improvements in cognition, 33 sleep, 27 and depression 25 have been revealed compared with a usual care control condition.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Most aerobic exercise studies in individuals with PD consisted of walking on a treadmill or stationary cycling.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Few studies have directly compared different modes of aerobic exercise, though no differences have been revealed when direct comparisons were made.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 18 Results across studies using different modes of aerobic exercise were comparable , 24 , 26 suggesting no single form of aerobic exercise was superior to another.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The intensity of aerobic exercise varied across studies.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Improvements have been observed with both moderate- and high-intensity aerobic exercise across a variety of outcomes.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Studies that have directly compared moderate- and high-intensity aerobic exercise 24 , 32 have found no differences between groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: This suggests a potential differential effect of high-intensity exercise on motor disease severity, though additional studies directly comparing moderate- and high-intensity aerobic exercise are needed to determine if there is a dose. response effect.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Functional outcomes and quality of life Aerobic exercise has also been shown to improve various aspects of function and quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Two high-quality 19 , 25 and 2 moderate-quality studies 29 , 32 revealed improvements in gait-related outcomes, including the 6-Minute Walk Test (6MWT) , 37 , 38 compared with usual care, strengthening, or low-intensity exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Other high-quality studies found improvements in balance and activities of daily living (ADLs) 22 , 25 compared with usual care or low-intensity exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Aerobic exercise has also been shown to improve global physical status or quality of life related to mobility 25 , 29 compared with a usual care control condition, though the evidence is limited to 1 high-quality and 1 moderate-quality study.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Aerobic exercise does not cause harm when therapists follow appropriate screening procedures to ensure there are no other medical conditions (eg, cardiac) that would preclude engagement in moderate- to high-intensity aerobic exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Some studies reveal that individuals with PD experienced minor musculoskeletal injuries with participation in aerobic exercise; however, most resolved without incident.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Gradually progressing the duration and intensity of the aerobic exercise is recommended to reduce risk of injury.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The mode of aerobic exercise should be chosen to ensure safe participation.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: For example, cycling rather than treadmill walking may be a safer aerobic exercise option in those who are at high risk of falling and/or with freezing of gait (FOG).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Future Research Additional studies are necessary to determine the optimal intensity of aerobic exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Large, adequately powered studies directly comparing high- and moderate-intensity exercise are needed to determine if high-intensity aerobic exercise is superior to moderate-intensity exercise in reducing motor disease severity and in improving functional outcomes and quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: It is also important to determine if the benefits of aerobic exercise modify symptoms versus the disease progression in people with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: More guidance on the optimal frequency and duration of aerobic exercise is also needed.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In addition, more studies are warranted to determine the effects of aerobic exercise on nonmotor outcomes (eg, cognition, depression, sleep, anxiety).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Furthermore, the adoption of a common set of outcome measures across aerobic exercise trials would facilitate the direct comparison of studies, thereby advancing the field forward more expeditiously.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgments Given the potential benefits of moderate- to high-intensity aerobic exercise to reduce motor disease severity in PD, the GDG recommends that physical therapists prescribe aerobic exercise very early in the course of the disease.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Though it is not clear whether the effects of aerobic exercise are disease modifying, the potential to reduce motor disease severity with aerobic exercise warrants early intervention.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Intentional Vagueness Given the variability in the dosing of aerobic exercise across studies, the optimal dosing of aerobic exercise has not been determined.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, many studies reveal a benefit of aerobic exercise when implemented at least 3 days per week for 30 to 40 minutes each at moderate to high intensity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Due to autonomic dysfunction leading to a blunted HR response in some individuals with PD, rate of perceived exertion should also be considered as a means of monitoring exercise intensity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 39 Although the length of the trials and timing of follow-up assessments vary considerably among studies, it appears that gains dissipate if exercise is discontinued.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: This suggests that regular, long-term engagement in aerobic exercise is needed to sustain a benefit.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Exclusions Most aerobic exercise studies include individuals with mild to moderate PD (H&Y stages 1.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: These recommendations may not apply to those with severe PD who do not have the capacity to engage in moderate- to high-intensity aerobic exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality Improvement Organizations may use documentation of moderate- to high-intensity aerobic exercise as a performance indicator.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Implementation and Audit Organizations may audit occurrence of documentation of moderate- to high-intensity aerobic exercise programs to improve VO 2 and functional outcomes and reduce motor disease severity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Resistance Training ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapists should implement resistance training to reduce motor disease severity and improve strength, power, nonmotor symptoms, functional outcomes, and quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 83 Rationale Strength and power Physical therapists should implement resistance training programs that are progressive in nature.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Benefits were observed whether resistance training was carried out alone or as part of a multimodal program to improve strength and power in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There were 3 high-quality 44 , 48 , 79 and 3 moderate-quality studies 73 , 81 , 82 that favor resistance training compared with control to improve strength and power.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The control groups in these studies included pharmacologic treatment alone; 26 , 30 nonexercise, education-based interventions 61 , 63 , 64 ; or a low-intensity home-based exercise intervention.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 55 When comparing resistance training with other modes of exercise, there are 2 high-quality studies 43 , 49 and 1 moderate-quality study 66 that favor resistance training to improve strength and power.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: A progressive resistance training program was shown to be more effective than a nonprogressive exercise intervention (modified from the Fitness Counts Booklet, Parkinson’s Foundation) for improving elbow flexion and extension torque 66 and elbow flexion torque.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 43 A progressive resistance training protocol using a weighted vest and ankle weights (60-minute class, twice weekly for 24 weeks) was superior to either tai chi or a stretching program to improve knee flexion and knee extension peak torque value as measured with use of isokinetic dynamometer.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 49 There was 1 high-quality 79 and 2 moderate-quality studies 61 , 81 that compared resistance training with other forms of resistance training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Resistance training with instability (RTI) was favored compared with resistance training alone to improve strength/power of the plantar flexors and knee extensors as measured via surface electromyography signals identified during submaximal isometric contractions on an isokinetic dynamometry.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 79 , 81 RTI is described as resistance training (leg press, latissimus dorsi pulldown, ankle plantar flexion, chest press, and half squat) with an added progressive and concomitant increase in resistance and instability applied via unstable devices (eg, balance pad, dyna discs, balance discs, BOSU, and Swiss ball).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In 1 moderate-quality study 61 strength training was favored compared with power training to improve strength/power as measured by the chest press normalized at 80% of 1-repetition maximum.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In this same study, power training was favored over strength training to improve strength/power as measured by the leg press normalized at 40% of 1-repetition maximum.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 52 and 2 moderate-quality studies 71 , 72 favored multimodal interventions that included resistance training compared with nonexercise, education-based controls to improve strength and power in people with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, 2 high-quality studies found no difference between multimodal interventions that included resistance training and usual care control groups to improve strength and power in people with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 40 , 41 Multimodal interventions that included resistance training were not superior to modes of intervention that did not include resistance training (low-intensity trunk exercise and turning training control 24 and nonexercise, education-based control 54 ) to improve lower extremity strength and power in individuals with PD, as indicated by 2 high-quality studies.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 42 , 72 However, 1 moderate-quality study 32 favored resistance training compared with high-intensity treadmill training to improve lower extremity strength via the leg press.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Nonmotor symptoms Physical therapists should implement resistance training that follows guidelines from the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) for progression to reduce nonmotor symptoms in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 84 There were 3 high-quality studies that favored resistance training compared with control (not engaged in exercise) to improve nonmotor function.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 44 , 46 , 79 There was 1 moderate-quality study 80 that favored resistance training compared with control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 44 favored progressive resistance training compared with a non-exercising control group (standard pharmacological treatment only) for depression (Hamilton Depression Rating Scale).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 85 Ferreira 46 favored resistance training over standard pharmacological treatment to improve anxiety (Beck Anxiety Inventory).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Two high-quality studies favored resistance training compared with a stretching, balance, and strengthening program 25 or a stretching intervention 31 to improve Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) motor scores.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There were 5 high-quality 44 , 45 , 50 , 55 , 57 and 1 moderate-quality study 80 that found no differences in disease severity when comparing resistance training with a control group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Functional outcomes There were 5 high-quality studies that favored resistance training compared with controls to improve function.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 44 , 48 , 50 , 55 , 79 Progressive resistance training was favored over a pharmacologic treatment to improve mobility (Timed “Up & Go” Test [TUG] and a 2-minute sit-to-stand), 26 , 30 gait speed, 26 , 30 flexibility, 26 and balance (Tinetti & Sit & Reach).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 30 Resistance training was favored over usual physical activity to improve fast gait speed on the 10-Meter Walk Test (10MWT) , 86 , 87 and progressive RTI was favored over a nonexercised, education-based intervention to improve balance (BESTest) and stability (Biodex Balance system).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 61 Progressive resistance training plus movement strategy training and falls education was favored over a control group that engaged in guided education and discussion to improve fall rate over 12 months and activities of daily living (UPDRS activities of daily living score).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 84 One high-quality study 79 and 3 moderate-quality studies 61 , 80 , 81 addressed 3 different modes of resistance training to improve balance and stability in people with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: RTI was favored over resistance training to improve balance on all domains of the BESTest except reactive postural responses and sensory orientation.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 79 RTI was also favored over resistance training to improve stability as measured by an overall stability index on the Biodex Balance System.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 78 , 79 The effects of resistance training on gait velocity were mixed.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 54 measured the effect of a 24-month progressive strengthening program of trunk and upper/lower extremity (PRET-PD) on gait velocity (m/s), stride length (m), cadence (steps/minute), and double support time (percentage of gait cycle).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Multimodal interventions Physical therapists should implement resistance training, either alone or as a part of a multimodal intervention, to improve function.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Three high-quality studies 22 , 47 , 72 favored multimodal interventions that included resistance training compared with control to improve balance as measured by the Mini BESTest , 88 , 89 the Functional Reach Test, and the Berg Balance Scale (BBS).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 22 Three high-quality studies 42 , 52 , 53 and 1 moderate-quality study 64 compared multimodal interventions that included a resistance training component to another active intervention (eg, power yoga, low-intensity exercise, turning-based training, conventional physical therapy).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: No clear pattern was observed to indicate superiority of multimodal interventions with a resistance training component versus other active interventions.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality of life There are 2 high-quality studies 46 , 55 that endorse the use of resistance training to improve quality of life compared with pharmacologic treatment 28 or usual care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 37 One high-quality study 25 and 1 moderate-quality study 16 favored resistance training over a multimodal program (Modified Fitness Counts) and over aerobic training to improve quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In contrast, there are 2 high-quality 44 , 50 and 3 moderate-quality studies 28 , 58 , 80 that found no difference in the effect of resistance training on quality of life compared with pharmacologic treatment, 44 , 58 a nonexercise education-based intervention, 50 , 80 or usual care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 28 Another high-quality study 40 endorsed resistance training as part of a multimodal intervention to improve quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: These findings suggest that implementing resistance training for individuals with PD can influence quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Improvements in strength/power Improvements in nonmotor symptoms (anxiety, cognition, depression) Reductions in motor disease severity Improvements in activities (gait speed, balance, mobility, stability) Improvements in quality of life Reduction in fall rate Risk, harms, and/or costs are as follows

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There are 6 studies 22 , 28 , 43 , 51 , 54 , 90 that found no significant difference in adverse events with resistance training compared with control or another active condition.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
