source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 259 Multimodal intervention Physical therapy is usually delivered in a multimodal manner, not targeting only 1 specific outcome but rather designed to improve multiple deficits of an individual with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 253 in an inpatient setting compared movement strategy training (cognitive-focused planning for movements, mental rehearsal, avoiding dual task, and cuing) with musculoskeletal exercise (focused on strengthening, ROM/flexibility, and postural alignment) and identified greater improvements in balance for the movement strategy training as measured by the Pull Test.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Another high-quality study 248 included functional training, functional strengthening, gait training overground and on treadmill, balance training, and recreational games compared with a medication-only control group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: They identified improvements in the targeted activities of daily living (ADLs- UPDRS II ), 34 , 35 motor disease severity ( UPDRS III ), 34 , 35 gait speed, and quality of life (SIP-68-Sickness impact profile) in the functional training group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: A moderate-quality study 260 compared aerobic training plus task-oriented circuit training with 11 different stations focused on balance, walking, and reaching to aerobic training alone.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 37 , 38 All the outcomes improved in both groups, with only the limits of stability, Pull Test, and postural stability demonstrating greater improvement in the task-oriented circuit training group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Improvement in the task that was specifically trained Improvement in upper extremity strength, dexterity, sensation, and goal attainment Improvement in mental imagery Improvement in turning and functional mobility Improvement in bladder function Risk, harms, and cost are as follows

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There is typically no increased cost to utilizing task-specific training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Future Research Additional studies are needed to determine the benefit of task-specific training for varying levels of cognition.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Additionally, studies are needed to determine the optimal dosage of task-specific training needed to optimize outcomes as well as to determine lasting effects of task-specific training to inform duration of training needed.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: It may be important to determine which impairments and functional tasks require task-specific training and which may improve by more general training to allow for greatest utilization of time.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgments Based on this evidence, task-specific training is important for individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Patient preference should be strongly considered when choosing targeted outcomes for task-specific training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Intentional Vagueness Given the variability in the dosing of task-specific training across studies, the optimal dosing has not been determined for any specific task.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, the studies with single-day training frequencies had less robust improvement than other studies with longer training durations.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Most studies looking at task-specific training utilized 30 to 90 minute sessions, 2 to 5 times a week, for 2 to 12 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Screening is required for the presence of comorbidities that may interfere with participation in task-specific training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality Improvement Organizations may use documentation of task-specific training as a performance indicator.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Implementation and Audit Organizations may audit occurrence of documentation of task specific training to improve task-specific impairment level and functional outcomes.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 268 Rationale Four high-quality and 5 moderate-quality studies examined the benefits of physical therapy and/or exercise interventions combined with behavior-change approaches in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: These studies varied considerably with regard to the types of behavior change approach used, outcomes measured, and comparison groups (usual medical care, self-guided exercise, and general physical therapy), which contributed to the GDG’s decision to downgrade the recommendation strength to moderate.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Motor disease severity One moderate-quality study 62 found that exercise combined with behavior-change approaches improved motor disease severity ( UPDRS-III ) compared with usual care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Bladder control One high-quality study 265 found that bladder retraining combined with behavior-change approaches improved bladder control-related outcomes compared with bladder diary alone.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Physical activity One high-quality study 263 of exercise combined with behavior-change approaches and 1 moderate-quality 267 study of physical therapist interventions using behavior-change approaches found physical activity improved in individuals with PD compared with self-guided exercise or physical therapy only.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In another high-quality study, 262 physical activity did not improve significantly following physical therapy with behavior-change approaches delivered using a mobile health application compared with physical therapy with a less intense behavior-change approach.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality of life One high-quality study 264 supported the use of physical therapy with behavior-change approaches to improve PD-related quality of life ( PDQ-39 ) 141 , 142 compared with general physical therapy and usual care control groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There are no significant risks or harms associated with the use of behavior change approaches with physical therapy compared with physical therapy alone.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Additional training of physical therapists may be necessary to optimize delivery of behavior change approaches within physical therapist practice.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Future Research Additional research is needed to determine the benefits of behavior change approaches combined with physical therapy compared with physical therapy alone to improve engagement in exercise and/or increase physical activity in persons with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Additional research is needed to identify the critical elements of behavior change approaches (eg, goal setting, action planning, feedback) that are most likely to result in optimal engagement in the desired behavior (eg, exercise, physical activity).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgments Given the importance of increasing self-efficacy and long-term engagement in exercise to optimize health in people with PD, the GDG recommends that physical therapists include behavior change approaches as part of their intervention.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 283 Integrated care approaches for individuals with PD involve a variety of professionals, which may include but are not limited to physical therapists or movement disorder specialists, neurologists, rehabilitation medicine providers, nurses, social workers, speech therapists, occupational therapists, and others.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In most studies, integrated care was compared with medical management by a neurologist only, except for Monticone, 273 which used a comparison with an exercise-only control group.
