target_name: 218 , 223 , 225 , 226 , 231 and 1 moderate-quality study 232 compared different gait training interventions and identified that walking outcomes improved regardless of the mode of gait training applied.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In 3 high-quality studies, both conventional treadmill training and RAGT indicated similar improvements in the distance covered during the 6MWT 37 , 38 and mobility as measured by the TUG.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 217 , 218 , 226 One high-quality study 231 identified improvement in mobility (TUG) after treadmill training both with and without repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Another high-quality study 223 compared a smartphone application that offered positive and corrective feedback during gait with gait training with personalized gait advice, finding similar improvements in the 2MWT for both groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One moderate-quality study favored Nordic walking on the treadmill compared with treadmill training alone to improve mobility.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 232 In all of the studies assessing the impact of gait training on mobility, only 1 high-quality study 109 and 1 moderate-quality study 233 did not find all gait training interventions to improve all functional mobility outcomes, although some improvements in each study were noted.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Balance Gait training has been shown to improve balance in individuals with PD, although there are some mixed results.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 102 identified improvements in balance and balance confidence as measured by the BBS and the ABC 143 in the group that participated in RAGT as well as in the group that participated in physical therapist intervention with an emphasis on balance and postural reactions.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Alternatively, RAGT resulted in improvements in balance as measured by the BBS compared with physical therapist intervention that did not focus on improvements in postural stability.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 228 Another high-quality study found that gait training with RAGT demonstrated greater improvement in balance as measured by the BBS compared with treadmill training alone or PNF-based (nonambulatory) physical therapist interventions.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 226 Similarly, a high-quality study identified improvements in balance as measured by the Functional Gait Assessment 138 , 139 using curved gait training on a treadmill compared with the control exercise group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 219 One moderate-quality study identified that incremental speed-dependent treadmill training had greater improvement than an inactive control group on balance as measured by the BBS and the Dynamic Gait index and fear of falling measured by the Falls Efficacy Scale.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 235 Another moderate-quality study identified improvements in balance as measured by the BBS in a group that participated in conventional gait training and a group that utilized body weight. supported treadmill training compared with an inactive control group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 239 Three high-quality 216 , 225 , 230 and 2 moderate-quality 232 , 237 studies compared different gait training interventions and found, regardless of the gait training method used, performing gait training improved balance outcomes, whereas 3 high-quality studies 100 , 109 , 223 found gait training interventions did not improve balance.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Furnari et al 237 compared RAGT plus a conventional exercise program with conventional gait training plus conventional exercise program, with both groups having similar significant improvements in balance (Tinetti balance scale).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Although both groups improved, Bang et al 232 found that Nordic walking on the treadmill had greater balance improvements than treadmill training alone (BBS).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study found that treadmill training with 0%, 5%, and 10% additional load applied using a weight belt during treadmill training had similar improvements in balance on the Pull Test.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 217 , 219 , 223 , 225 Two high-quality studies found improvement with gait training including RGAT, treadmill training, and circular treadmill training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 217 , 219 Two high-quality studies found that gait training did not improve FOG with gait training, including treadmill training, a FOG phone app that included biofeedback with gait training, and gait training with FOG-specific advice.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The high-quality study found that treadmill training decreased falls and fear of falling.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 225 One moderate-quality study found falls decreased during the 6 months post treadmill training with and without VR, 241 but a similar study found only a trend toward decreasing falls.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 242 Fatigue Two high-quality studies indicated that fatigue improved with treadmill training and RAGT but no improvement in control groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgments Given that a decline in walking ability occurs over the disease continuum in PD and that gait training improves walking and other functional outcomes, the GDG recommends initiating gait training early after diagnosis to optimize walking-related outcomes.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, many studies reveal a benefit of gait training when implemented 20 to 60 minutes, 3 to 5 days per week, for 4 to 12 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Gait training may need to be a continued activity to decrease the decline in functional outcomes.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There was no single gait training intervention that demonstrated greater improvement than other types of gait training (eg, overground vs treadmill vs robotic assisted).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality Improvement Organizations may use documentation of gait training as a performance indicator.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Implementation and Audit Organizations may audit occurrence of documentation of gait training to reduce motor disease severity and improve stride length, gait speed, mobility, and balance.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Task-Specific Training ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapists should implement task-specific training to improve task-specific impairment level and functional outcomes for individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Overall, studies suggest that task-specific training improves the outcome targeted using a variety of approaches.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Mental imagery Task-specific mental imagery (with sufficient repetitions) paired with actively performing the task resulted in improvements in the target outcome.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 244 , 245 When functional outcomes were assessed following dynamic neurocognitive imagery mental imagery, there was an improvement in 6MWT 37 , 38 and TUG but not pain, UPDRS, ABC , 143 30-second chair stand test, Mini-BESTest , 88 , 89 TUG dual task , 172 or 360 degree turn.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 244 Watching videos of individuals with and without PD walk and being trained to discriminate between them (8 days of training) did not demonstrate any spatiotemporal gait improvements either at home or in a laboratory environment.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 250 Locomotor imagery including 10 minutes of watching their own gait and that of an adult male without PD from various views in addition to physical therapist interventions, however, improved lower extremity joint kinematics and functional gait ( Functional Gait Assessment ) 138 , 139 compared with physical therapist services alone.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 247 One moderate-quality study found no significant improvement in functional gait outcomes ( 10MWT 86 , 87 or TUG) when utilizing mental imagery embedded in the therapy session.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Upper extremity Task-specific training that is focused on the upper extremities should improve strength and manual dexterity and may improve sensation and goal attainment.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Three high-quality studies 246 , 252 , 255 focused on upper extremity impairments (weakness, poor manual dexterity, and decreased sensation), and 1 moderate-quality study 261 focused on upper extremity function (goal attainment).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 261 This study did not find an improvement in haptic object test recognition or functional use as assessed with the box and box test.

target_name: 42 The study found that both the turning-based rotational treadmill program and turning-specific exercise group had greater turning improvement than the general exercise group, indicating the benefit of task-specific training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 169 Dual task Physical therapists may consider using dual-task training to improve functional dual-task walking, because there were mixed results in the 3 high-quality studies focused on specifically training dual tasks in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 249 , 251 , 254 One high-quality study found decreased dual-task cost on gait speed, improved balance ( Mini-BESTest ), 88 , 89 and improved perception of FOG (FOG-Q) 140 when comparing agility boot camp utilizing cognitive challenges during tasks compared with education as the control (80 minutes, 3 times a week for 6 weeks).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Both dual- and single-task training (70 minutes, 2 times a week for 6 weeks) demonstrated similar improvements as measured by dual-task gait speed and spatiotemporal gait parameters during dual-task walking under 3 different dual-task conditions (with auditory stroop, backward digit span, and using a mobile phone).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 249 , 254 Falls Interventions focused on task-specific training to decrease falls have mixed results, with 1 high-quality study 50 demonstrating decreased falls and 1 moderate-quality study 121 demonstrating no difference in falls.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The high-quality study had 3 groups, including fall prevention education with movement strategy training (strategies to prevent falls and improve mobility and balance during functional tasks using attention

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The moderate-quality study showed task-specific training for fall prevention that included a home assessment of fall risk factors, strengthening and balance training, and functional practice of turning and complex environments improved balance, fear of falling, and ability to get out of a chair, but it did not decrease falls compared with an inactive control group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 121 This study also found that task-specific training for fall prevention may increase fall risk in individuals at the H&Y stage 4 and have better improvement in moderate disease severity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Bladder training One moderate study looked at lower urinary tract symptoms in individuals with PD and found that task-specific training for bladder management versus conservative advice improved number of voids per day and amount voided with each micturition and decreased incontinence and bladder interference with daily life, but it did not improve overall quality of life or urgency.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 259 Multimodal intervention Physical therapy is usually delivered in a multimodal manner, not targeting only 1 specific outcome but rather designed to improve multiple deficits of an individual with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 253 in an inpatient setting compared movement strategy training (cognitive-focused planning for movements, mental rehearsal, avoiding dual task, and cuing) with musculoskeletal exercise (focused on strengthening, ROM/flexibility, and postural alignment) and identified greater improvements in balance for the movement strategy training as measured by the Pull Test.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Behavior-Change Approach ♦♦♦◊ Physical therapists should implement behavior-change approaches to improve physical activity and quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 268 Rationale Four high-quality and 5 moderate-quality studies examined the benefits of physical therapy and/or exercise interventions combined with behavior-change approaches in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Motor disease severity One moderate-quality study 62 found that exercise combined with behavior-change approaches improved motor disease severity ( UPDRS-III ) compared with usual care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Bladder control One high-quality study 265 found that bladder retraining combined with behavior-change approaches improved bladder control-related outcomes compared with bladder diary alone.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Physical activity One high-quality study 263 of exercise combined with behavior-change approaches and 1 moderate-quality 267 study of physical therapist interventions using behavior-change approaches found physical activity improved in individuals with PD compared with self-guided exercise or physical therapy only.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In another high-quality study, 262 physical activity did not improve significantly following physical therapy with behavior-change approaches delivered using a mobile health application compared with physical therapy with a less intense behavior-change approach.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality of life One high-quality study 264 supported the use of physical therapy with behavior-change approaches to improve PD-related quality of life ( PDQ-39 ) 141 , 142 compared with general physical therapy and usual care control groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, a moderate-quality study 62 revealed no improvement in quality of life compared with usual care using non. disease-specific quality-of-life measures (EQ-5D and SF-36).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Improved participation

target_name: disease-related quality of life and physical activity Improved activities

target_name: walking capacity Improved body structure and function

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Enhancing behavior change approaches with psychoeducation 263 and mobile health technology 262 may increase the costs for the health care team and/or for the patient but may also mitigate costs for patients and care partners related to reduced travel to the health care facility.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Benefit-harm assessment: The balance of the benefits versus risk, harms, or cost supports this recommendation.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Future Research Additional research is needed to determine the benefits of behavior change approaches combined with physical therapy compared with physical therapy alone to improve engagement in exercise and/or increase physical activity in persons with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The benefits of behavior change approaches are not known among people with greater disease severity or cognitive impairments.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality Improvement Organizations may use documentation of behavior-change approaches as a performance indicator.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Implementation and Audit Organizations may audit occurrence of documentation of behavior-change approaches to improve physical activity and quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Integrated Care ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapist services should be delivered within an integrated care approach to reduce motor disease severity and improve quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Integrated care approaches include multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and interprofessional health care teams working to improve quality and safety of services provided to people with medically complex needs.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Motor disease severity Three high-quality studies revealed reductions in motor disease severity ( UPDRS-III ) 34 , 35 with integrated care compared with control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 271 , 272 The third study compared 8 weeks of inpatient rehabilitation with a multidisciplinary approach including physical therapy, occupational therapy, and cognitive training provided by psychologists with inpatient physical therapy alone for 8 weeks, finding improved UPDRS-III 34 , 35 scores in the group receiving multidisciplinary care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 273 Three additional moderate-quality studies supported that UPDRS-III 34 , 35 scores were improved compared with medical management alone using varied integrated care approaches, including

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 277 The addition of aquatic therapy to the integrated care team in an intensive inpatient rehabilitation environment was not associated with any significant benefits in UPDRS-III .

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 34 , 35 , 269 Nonmotor symptoms Three moderate-quality studies reported improved nonmotor symptoms (anxiety, depression, and psychosocial consequences) following various integrated care approaches compared with usual medical care control groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study found improvements in walking activities including gait speed and spatiotemporal gait parameters, physical performance, and stability (tandem stance and Pastor test).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 275 Another high-quality study revealed improvements in balance as measured by the BBS.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 273 Two high-quality studies supported improvements in activities of daily living compared with control 271 , 273 ; however, 1 moderate-quality study indicated no difference in activities of daily living between a group receiving physical therapist services and occupational therapist services compared with a group that received no therapy.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 276 Quality-of-life outcomes Three high-quality studies supported improvements in health-related quality of life ( PDQ-39 ) 141 , 142 with integrated care compared with usual medical care control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The integrated care model that included neurologists, physiatrists, psychologists, nurses, physical therapists, and occupational therapists resulted in no significant increase in LEDD 278 compared with the usual care group where a significant increase in the LEDD was observed, suggesting worsening disease severity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In 1 study, the group with more team members (12 team members vs 6), had a greater improvement in quality of life ( PDQ-39 ).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 279 MDT followed by PCA had better quality of life outcomes (less long-term decline in mental component of SF36; EQ5D slightly improved).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: At 6 weeks, there was a beneficial effect of increased rehabilitation hours on quality of life ( PDQ-39 ), 141 , 142 and effects persisted at 6 months.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 264 , 268 Potential Benefits, Risks, Harms, and Cost of Implementing This Recommendation Benefits are as follows

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One moderate-quality study 279 suggested that compared with usual medical management care, the integrated care model was associated with improved pain management (Pain Visual Analog Scale on medication) but also with more accident and emergency adverse events.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: True interdisciplinary integrated care approaches, which would require team meetings and increased lines of communication between physicians and physical therapists, may present a greater challenge in some organizations.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In addition, more research is needed on the long-term benefits and costs related to health care utilization, hospitalizations, falls, and institutionalization related to maintaining integrated care approaches from diagnosis to advanced PD care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Quality Improvement Organizations may use documentation of interprofessional, multi-disciplinary, or interdisciplinary health care teams as a performance indicator.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Implementation and Audit Organizations may audit occurrence of interprofessional, multi-disciplinary, or interdisciplinary health care teams to improve quality and safety of services provided to people with medically complex needs.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Telerehabilitation ♦♦◊◊ Physical therapist services may be delivered via telerehabilitation to improve balance in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 262 showed that quality of life, walking capacity ( 6MWT ), 37 , 38 and physical activity did not improve significantly with a mobile health-mediated behavior change approach compared with a less-intense intervention using activity diaries.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, the intervention using a mobile health application appeared to differentially benefit the less active subgroup for improvement in health-related quality-of-life mobility subscore ( PDQ-39 mobility score).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Potential Benefits, Risks, Harms, and Cost of Implementing This Recommendation Benefits are as follows: Improved activities: balance Improved participation Risk, harms, and/or cost are as follows: The studies included reported no significant differences in adverse events between the telerehabilitation/mobile health and control groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The use of mobile health technology may increase the costs for the health care team or for the patient but may also decrease costs related to travel and access to care for patients and care partners.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Future Research Further research is needed with robust study designs to examine the benefits of telerehabilitation and mobile health technology for safety, feasibility (and usability for patients and providers), efficacy for disease severity, physical function, quality of life, physical activity, and cost and resource utilization.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgments Besides the reduced burden of travel, access, inclement weather, and other barriers to long-term engagement in in-person programs, the utilization of telerehabilitation is especially important in light of low referral rates (14.2%) to rehabilitation and inequitable care with referral rates even lower in African American patients (7.6%).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: This CPG should not be construed as including all proper methods of care or excluding methods of care reasonably directed at obtaining the same results.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The ultimate judgment regarding the application of any specific procedure or treatment must be made considering all circumstances presented by the individual, including safety, preferences, and disease stage, as well as the needs and resources particular to the locality or institution.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Care for individuals with PD is based on decisions made by them in consultation with their health care team, which may comprise movement disorder specialists, general neurologists, geriatricians, primary care physicians, nurses, physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, registered dieticians, social workers, and other professionals.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: APTA sought out the expertise of the AAOS Evidence-Based Medicine Unit as paid consultants to assist in the methodology of this CPG.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The mode of aerobic exercise should be chosen to ensure safe participation.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: For example, cycling rather than treadmill walking may be a safer aerobic exercise option in those who are at high risk of falling and/or with freezing of gait (FOG).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Due to autonomic dysfunction leading to a blunted HR response in some individuals with PD, rate of perceived exertion should also be considered as a means of monitoring exercise intensity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 128 There were no significant changes in impairment measures in 3 high-quality studies of primarily home-based, minimally supervised interventions compared with control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 119 , 121 Mobility improved in individuals with PD when a supervised multimodal balance program was implemented 2 to 3 times per week, 16 to 30 total hours, for at least 5 and up to 10 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, balance training that was a primarily home-based, minimally supervised intervention did not show significant improvements in mobility.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 41 , 47 , 91 , 115 , 116 , 119 Interestingly, 1 high-quality study using a 6-month duration, primarily home-based, minimally supervised exercise program targeting fall risk factors found that falls were reduced in individuals with mild PD, but not in people with more severe PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 107 Supervision One high-quality study 99 and 1 moderate-quality study 120 compared more supervised with less supervised balance interventions.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Continued comparative studies are also needed to determine if supervised or unsupervised programs are superior for improving flexibility.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Intentional Vagueness Given the limited research available, recommendations regarding target muscle groups, dosing parameters, mode of flexibility exercise, and supervised versus unsupervised exercise cannot be made.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Gait training with external cues should not cause harm if routine safety procedures are followed.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: These studies measured quality of life using a variety of measurements, including the PDQ-39 and -8 , 141 , 142 Holistic Well-Being Scale, and Parkinson’s Disease Quality of Life Questionnaire.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 223 Freezing of gait Four high-quality studies monitored FOG with gait training with mixed results.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 223 , 225 Falls Only 1 high-quality study 225 and 2 moderate-quality 241 , 242 studies monitored falls after gait training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Gait training should not cause harm if routine safety procedures are followed.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Individuals who are at high risk for falls may require a harness or safety device to optimize safety.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Integrated Care ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapist services should be delivered within an integrated care approach to reduce motor disease severity and improve quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 282 providing strong evidence comparing an integrated care approach to control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Integrated care approaches include multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and interprofessional health care teams working to improve quality and safety of services provided to people with medically complex needs.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 283 Integrated care approaches for individuals with PD involve a variety of professionals, which may include but are not limited to physical therapists or movement disorder specialists, neurologists, rehabilitation medicine providers, nurses, social workers, speech therapists, occupational therapists, and others.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In most studies, integrated care was compared with medical management by a neurologist only, except for Monticone, 273 which used a comparison with an exercise-only control group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Motor disease severity Three high-quality studies revealed reductions in motor disease severity ( UPDRS-III ) 34 , 35 with integrated care compared with control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 273 Three additional moderate-quality studies supported that UPDRS-III 34 , 35 scores were improved compared with medical management alone using varied integrated care approaches, including

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 277 The addition of aquatic therapy to the integrated care team in an intensive inpatient rehabilitation environment was not associated with any significant benefits in UPDRS-III .

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 34 , 35 , 269 Nonmotor symptoms Three moderate-quality studies reported improved nonmotor symptoms (anxiety, depression, and psychosocial consequences) following various integrated care approaches compared with usual medical care control groups.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 279 Functional outcomes (gait, mobility, balance, and activities of daily living) Three high-quality studies 271 , 273 , 275 and 2 moderate-quality studies 278 , 282 favored integrated care versus control for functional activities, but there was high variability in the functional measures used across studies.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 276 Quality-of-life outcomes Three high-quality studies supported improvements in health-related quality of life ( PDQ-39 ) 141 , 142 with integrated care compared with usual medical care control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 273 Two additional moderate-quality studies supported the finding that integrated care was associated with better quality-of-life outcomes compared with medical management alone.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 276 , 281 Levodopa equivalent daily dose One high-quality study 271 and 3 moderate-quality studies 277 , 278 , 281 compared the effect of an integrated care model with usual medical care on levodopa equivalent daily dose (LEDD).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The integrated care model that included neurologists, physiatrists, psychologists, nurses, physical therapists, and occupational therapists resulted in no significant increase in LEDD 278 compared with the usual care group where a significant increase in the LEDD was observed, suggesting worsening disease severity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Comparisons of types of integrated care models One high-quality 269 and 2 moderate-quality studies 279 , 280 compared integrated care models with different numbers of providers.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 279 One high-quality study 264 and 1 moderate-quality study 268 from the same trial compared an integrated self-management approach with usual care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 273 and 1 moderate-quality study 276 found that there were no significant differences in adverse events in those who participated in integrated care versus a control condition.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One moderate-quality study 279 suggested that compared with usual medical management care, the integrated care model was associated with improved pain management (Pain Visual Analog Scale on medication) but also with more accident and emergency adverse events.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One moderate-quality study 279 directly measured costs and found no significant differences in the overall health care costs between 2 integrated care approaches (multidisciplinary care and multidisciplinary care combined with extra caregiver support).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Use of integrated care approaches varies widely across health care organizations.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: True interdisciplinary integrated care approaches, which would require team meetings and increased lines of communication between physicians and physical therapists, may present a greater challenge in some organizations.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Future Research The research supporting integrated care approaches over usual care or neurologist care alone is promising.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, additional high-quality research is needed regarding the optimal time to initiate integrated care and the composition of the team.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In addition, more research is needed on the long-term benefits and costs related to health care utilization, hospitalizations, falls, and institutionalization related to maintaining integrated care approaches from diagnosis to advanced PD care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgment Due to the complex nature of signs and symptoms associated with PD, the GDG suggests adopting an integrated care approach for management of PD over the course of the disease.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 284 Intentional Vagueness Our description of integrated care approaches is intentionally vague due to the heterogeneity of intervention types and timing.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Keywords: Clinical, Clinical Guidelines, Decision-Making, Parkinson Disease Introduction Overview This clinical practice guideline (CPG) is based on a systematic review of published studies involving the physical therapist management of individuals with Parkinson disease (PD).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Care for individuals with PD is based on decisions made by them in consultation with their health care team, which may comprise movement disorder specialists, general neurologists, geriatricians, primary care physicians, nurses, physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, registered dieticians, social workers, and other professionals.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

target_name: Weak ♦♦ ◊◊ A moderate level of certainty of slight benefit, harms, or cost, or a low level of certainty for moderate-to-substantial benefit, harms, or cost (based on Level II thru V evidence).

target_name: Resistance Training ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapists should implement resistance training to reduce motor disease severity and improve strength, power, nonmotor symptoms, functional outcomes, and quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 83 Rationale Strength and power Physical therapists should implement resistance training programs that are progressive in nature.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: A progressive resistance training program was shown to be more effective than a nonprogressive exercise intervention (modified from the Fitness Counts Booklet, Parkinson’s Foundation) for improving elbow flexion and extension torque 66 and elbow flexion torque.

target_name: 49 There was 1 high-quality 79 and 2 moderate-quality studies 61 , 81 that compared resistance training with other forms of resistance training.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Nonmotor symptoms Physical therapists should implement resistance training that follows guidelines from the American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) for progression to reduce nonmotor symptoms in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Two high-quality studies favored resistance training compared with a stretching, balance, and strengthening program 25 or a stretching intervention 31 to improve Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) motor scores.

target_name: Balance Training ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapists should implement balance training intervention programs to reduce postural control impairments and improve balance and gait outcomes, mobility, balance confidence, and quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Common among these intervention programs was an emphasis on multidirectional stepping, motor agility, anticipatory postural control, and reactive balance.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

target_name: Community-Based Exercise ♦♦♦♦ Physical therapists should recommend community-based exercise to reduce motor disease severity and improve nonmotor symptoms, functional outcomes, and quality of life in individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Community-based exercise is defined in this CPG as follows: (1) programs in which groups of individuals exercise together; or (2) programs in which individuals follow a predetermined exercise program in a community setting either at home or in a community facility.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: These programs often include a home exercise component.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Nonmotor symptoms Two high-quality studies 179 , 185 and 1 moderate-quality study 214 found that community-based exercise improved depression as measured by the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale, Beck Depression Inventory, and the Geriatric Depression Scale, and improved cognition as measured by Montreal Cognitive Assessment , 85 Mini-Mental State Examination, and Wechsler Memory.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study found improvements in sleep as measured by the Parkinson Disease Sleep Scale.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 173 The studies that improved nonmotor symptoms all included interventions for breathing and relaxation, with frequency and duration ranging from 1 to 2 hours per week for 8 to 25 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: These community-based exercise programs included tai chi, 175 resistance training, 53 action observation training, 181 dance, 177 , 184 , 195 balance exercise and lower extremity strengthening, 40 , 41 , 47 , 83 Pilates, 192 , 194 Nordic walk, 193 qigong, 201 mindful meditation, 214 Feldenkrais, 212 and power yoga.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Several studies have made direct comparisons between community-based exercise programs. source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgments Besides the reduced burden of travel, access, inclement weather, and other barriers to long-term engagement in in-person programs, the utilization of telerehabilitation is especially important in light of low referral rates (14.2%) to rehabilitation and inequitable care with referral rates even lower in African American patients (7.6%).

target_name: Neurological care is provided in diverse settings by many different providers.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Neurologists, adult primary care clinicians, geriatricians, rehabilitation medicine provider, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, and other health care professionals who routinely see individuals with PD in various practice settings also may benefit from this guideline.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 1 Once the individual (or advocate) has been informed of the nature of the available therapies and their rationale, duration, benefits, risks, and costs and has discussed the options with their health care provider, an informed and shared decision can be made.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 4 The total US economic burden of PD was estimated to be $51.9 billion in 2017, with $25.4 billion representing direct medical costs and $26.5 billion representing indirect and nonmedical costs, including premature death and lost employment of people with PD and their care partners.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 3 In the United States, people with PD are hospitalized 1.44 times more than those without the disease and experience rehospitalization at a higher rate.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Emotional and Physical Impact Disease duration in those diagnosed with PD can span decades.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: The guideline development group (GDG) consisted of physical therapist members from APTA and its representative sections and academies, AAOS, the American Parkinson’s Disease Association, and a neurologist from the American Academy of Neurology ( Fig. 1 ).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: This CPG was prepared by the APTA Parkinson Disease Clinical Practice Guideline Development Group (clinical experts) with the assistance of the AAOS Clinical Quality and Value Department (methodologists).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Rating Quality of Evidence Rating of Overall Quality of Evidence Definition High Preponderance of Level I or II evidence with at least 1 Level I study.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Moderate Preponderance of Level II evidence.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Strength of Recommendations Strength Strength Visual Definition Strong ♦♦♦♦ A high level of certainty of moderate-to-substantial benefit, harms, or cost, or a moderate level of certainty for substantial benefit, harms, or cost (based on a preponderance [2 or more] of Level I or II evidence with at least 1 Level I study).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Moderate ♦♦♦ ◊ A high level of certainty of slight-to-moderate benefit, harms, or cost, or a moderate level of certainty for a moderate level of benefit, harms, or cost (based on a preponderance of Level II evidence, or a single high-quality randomized controlled trial).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Theoretical/ foundational ♦ ◊◊◊ A preponderance of evidence from animal or cadaver studies, from conceptual/theoretical models/principles, or from basic science/bench research, or published expert opinion in peer-reviewed journals that supports the recommendation.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: More recently, a CPG recommending a core set of outcome measures for adults with neurological conditions was published as an effort to streamline the assessments utilized across patients with neurological conditions.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Role of the Funding Source The American Physical Therapy Association, which funded the travel for 1 GDG meeting and for the AAOS services, provided coordination but played no other role in the design and conduct of this CPG or in the reporting of the recommendations.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: It has been suggested that dopaminergic replacement medications may mask the benefits of exercise, thus potentially accounting for lack of effects of aerobic exercise on motor symptoms when measured in the “on” state.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Two high-quality 19 , 25 and 2 moderate-quality studies 29 , 32 revealed improvements in gait-related outcomes, including the 6-Minute Walk Test (6MWT) , 37 , 38 compared with usual care, strengthening, or low-intensity exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Other high-quality studies found improvements in balance and activities of daily living (ADLs) 22 , 25 compared with usual care or low-intensity exercise.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Gradually progressing the duration and intensity of the aerobic exercise is recommended to reduce risk of injury.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: More guidance on the optimal frequency and duration of aerobic exercise is also needed.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Furthermore, the adoption of a common set of outcome measures across aerobic exercise trials would facilitate the direct comparison of studies, thereby advancing the field forward more expeditiously.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, many studies reveal a benefit of aerobic exercise when implemented at least 3 days per week for 30 to 40 minutes each at moderate to high intensity.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 43 A progressive resistance training protocol using a weighted vest and ankle weights (60-minute class, twice weekly for 24 weeks) was superior to either tai chi or a stretching program to improve knee flexion and knee extension peak torque value as measured with use of isokinetic dynamometer.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In 1 moderate-quality study 61 strength training was favored compared with power training to improve strength/power as measured by the chest press normalized at 80% of 1-repetition maximum.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In this same study, power training was favored over strength training to improve strength/power as measured by the leg press normalized at 40% of 1-repetition maximum.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 44 , 48 , 50 , 55 , 79 Progressive resistance training was favored over a pharmacologic treatment to improve mobility (Timed “Up & Go” Test [TUG] and a 2-minute sit-to-stand), 26 , 30 gait speed, 26 , 30 flexibility, 26 and balance (Tinetti & Sit & Reach).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 61 Progressive resistance training plus movement strategy training and falls education was favored over a control group that engaged in guided education and discussion to improve fall rate over 12 months and activities of daily living (UPDRS activities of daily living score).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: One high-quality study 54 measured the effect of a 24-month progressive strengthening program of trunk and upper/lower extremity (PRET-PD) on gait velocity (m/s), stride length (m), cadence (steps/minute), and double support time (percentage of gait cycle).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: In these studies, adverse events included strains and sprains, delayed onset muscle soreness, fatigue, cardiovascular events, pain, and falls.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 35 , 76 In 1 study, injurious falls were reported; however, there were similar rates of injurious falls in the experimental group (progressive resistance strength training and movement strategy training) and the control group (education-based life skills training).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Of importance, a common set of outcome measures is needed across these trials to allow direct comparison of results.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Value Judgments Physical therapists should be aware that improvement in outcomes due to resistance training is likely dose specific (eg, greater improvement in outcomes with longer duration or higher intensity of resistance training.) Some outcomes that did not show change with resistance training may show change after implementation of a longer or more intense resistance training dose.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, many studies reveal a benefit of resistance exercise when implemented 1 to 2 days per week for 30 to 60 minutes while applying 80% of the repetition maximum to achieve strength gains and 40% of the repetition maximum to improve power.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Studies also support progressively increasing the load by 2% when 3 sets of 15 repetitions are achieved with good form.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Additional balance measures reported in the high-quality articles included BBS and single-leg stance.

target_name: High-quality studies that demonstrated favorable outcomes ranged in frequency (2.

target_name: 119 , 121 Mobility improved in individuals with PD when a supervised multimodal balance program was implemented 2 to 3 times per week, 16 to 30 total hours, for at least 5 and up to 10 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Due to variability in settings, frequency, and delivery patterns, session durations ranged from 30 to 120 minutes.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 41 , 47 , 91 , 115 , 116 , 119 Interestingly, 1 high-quality study using a 6-month duration, primarily home-based, minimally supervised exercise program targeting fall risk factors found that falls were reduced in individuals with mild PD, but not in people with more severe PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 41 Similarly, another moderate-quality study found in a secondary analysis that individuals with more moderate disease but not severe disease had decreased fall rates in the experimental group.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Two high-quality 95 , 114 and 2 moderate-quality studies 119 , 121 demonstrated no difference in physical activity as measured by daily steps or the Physical Activity Scale for the Elderly between a balance training intervention and usual care.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, few studies reported adverse events, but those that did reported a small number of adverse events that were minor in nature and found no difference in number of adverse events between intervention groups and control.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 119 , 121 One study published cost-effectiveness data, 127 noting that balance intervention provided in a group setting was more costly than the usual care control group but yielded greater gains in balance, gait, and quality-adjusted life years for individuals with PD.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, many studies reveal a benefit of balance training when implemented 2 to 3 times per week for 16 to 30 total hours over 5 to 10 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 170 , 171 These studies varied considerably regarding sample size, comparison group, outcomes measured, mode, frequency, duration, and type of external cueing.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Cueing in all these studies was delivered between 20 minutes to 1 hour, 2 to 5 times per week for 3 to 8 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 167 One moderate-quality study identified that music delivered continuously during overground walking was superior to music that played only if the participant achieved a predetermined stride length via a preprogrammed wearable sensor.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 158 Two moderate-quality studies favored an attentional strategy using cues to produce large amplitude whole body movements Lee Silverman Voice Treatment physical or occupational therapy improves mobility and movement used in everyday function (LSVT BIG) delivered for 1 hour, 4 times per week for 8 weeks compared with 1 hour of Nordic walking 2 times per week for 8 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 163 LSVT BIG was also favored over a shortened amplitude-oriented training delivered 5 times per week for 2 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 159 Cueing interventions in all of these studies was delivered 2 to 5 times per week for 3 to 8 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: An additional high-quality study 150 identified that visual and auditory cues delivered during gait training on a treadmill instrumented with a visual display were superior to visual and auditory cues provided during overground gait training to improve gait speed, measured using an instrumented treadmill, and delivered 7 times per week for 4 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: More studies are needed to determine optimal dosing to sustain benefits over time (eg, ongoing use vs booster sessions).

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Community-based exercise is defined in this CPG as follows: (1) programs in which groups of individuals exercise together; or (2) programs in which individuals follow a predetermined exercise program in a community setting either at home or in a community facility.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 34 , 35 All of the high-quality studies consisted of varied interventions (yoga, dance, Pilates, power training); however, the doses were consistent (1-hour sessions 2 times per week for 12.

target_name: There was greater variability in dosing in the moderate-quality studies with a minimum of 16 sessions and a maximum of 96 sessions, ranging from 1 time per week for 16 weeks to 2 times per week for 12 months.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: 173 The studies that improved nonmotor symptoms all included interventions for breathing and relaxation, with frequency and duration ranging from 1 to 2 hours per week for 8 to 25 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There was no consistent difference in dose or mode of exercise that might explain this discrepancy.

target_name: 217 , 218 , 226 One high-quality study 231 identified improvement in mobility (TUG) after treadmill training both with and without repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: There is a risk of musculoskeletal discomfort with gait training (eg, lower extremity or back pain), which was occasionally reported.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Last, a standard set of outcomes should be used across studies to facilitate direct comparisons between studies.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: However, many studies reveal a benefit of gait training when implemented 20 to 60 minutes, 3 to 5 days per week, for 4 to 12 weeks.

source_title: Physical Therapist Management of Parkinson Disease: A Clinical Practice Guideline From the American Physical Therapy Association
target_name: Mental imagery Task-specific mental imagery (with sufficient repetitions) paired with actively performing the task resulted in improvements in the target outcome.
