target_name: 10.1002/14651858.CD009790.pub2 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract Background

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Low back pain has been the leading cause of disability globally for at least the past three decades and results in enormous direct healthcare and lost productivity costs.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Objectives: The primary objective of this systematic review is to assess the impact of exercise treatment on pain and functional limitations in adults with chronic non-specific low back pain compared to no treatment, usual care, placebo and other conservative treatments.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: We searched CENTRAL (which includes the Cochrane Back and Neck trials register), MEDLINE, Embase, CINAHL, PsycINFO, PEDro, SPORTDiscus, and trials registries (ClinicalTrials.gov and World Health Organization International Clinical Trials Registry Platform), and conducted citation searching of relevant systematic reviews to identify additional studies.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Twelve included studies reported measuring adverse effects in a systematic way, with a median of 0.14 (IQR 0.01 to 0.57) per participant in the exercise groups (mostly minor harms, e.g. muscle soreness), and 0.12 (IQR 0.02 to 0.32) in comparison groups.

target_name: PMID: 34580864 PMCID: PMC8477273 DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD009790.pub2 Item in Clipboard Meta-Analysis Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain Jill A Hayden et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev .

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Low back pain has been the leading cause of disability globally for at least the past three decades and results in enormous direct healthcare and lost productivity costs.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Objectives: The primary objective of this systematic review is to assess the impact of exercise treatment on pain and functional limitations in adults with chronic non-specific low back pain compared to no treatment, usual care, placebo and other conservative treatments.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Selection criteria: We included randomised controlled trials that assessed exercise treatment compared to no treatment, usual care, placebo or other conservative treatment on the outcomes of pain or functional limitations for a population of adult participants with chronic non-specific low back pain of more than 12 weeks' duration.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: We extracted outcome data using electronic databases; pain and functional limitations outcomes were re-scaled to 0 to 100 points for meta-analyses where 0 is no pain or functional limitations.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: To interpret meta-analysis results, we considered a 15-point difference in pain and a 10-point difference in functional limitations outcomes to be clinically important for the primary comparison of exercise versus no treatment, usual care or placebo.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: We found moderate-certainty evidence that exercise treatment is more effective for treatment of chronic low back pain compared to no treatment, usual care or placebo comparisons for pain outcomes at earliest follow-up (MD -15.2, 95% CI -18.3 to -12.2), a clinically important difference.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Compared to all other investigated conservative treatments, exercise treatment was found to have improved pain (MD -9.1, 95% CI -12.6 to -5.6) and functional limitations outcomes (MD -4.1, 95% CI -6.0 to -2.2).

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Subgroup analysis of pain outcomes suggested that exercise treatment is probably more effective than education alone (MD -12.2, 95% CI -19.4 to -5.0) or non-exercise physical therapy (MD -10.4, 95% CI -15.2 to -5.6), but with no differences observed for manual therapy (MD 1.0, 95% CI -3.1 to 5.1).

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: Authors' conclusions: We found moderate-certainty evidence that exercise is probably effective for treatment of chronic low back pain compared to no treatment, usual care or placebo for pain.

source_title: Exercise therapy for chronic low back pain
target_name: We also found exercise to have improved pain (low-certainty evidence) and functional limitations outcomes (moderate-certainty evidence) compared to other conservative treatments; however, these effects were small and not clinically important when considering all comparisons together.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: Exercise interventions improve physical function and quality of life in individuals with musculoskeletal pain, yet optimal exercise prescription variables (e.g. duration, frequency, intensity) are unclear.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: Objective: We aimed to examine evidence gaps, methodological quality and exercise prescription recommendations in systematic reviews of exercise for musculoskeletal pain.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: We included peer-reviewed, English language, systematic reviews and meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and controlled clinical trials (CCTs) that compared exercise with conservative treatment, placebo or other exercise interventions in adults with musculoskeletal pain.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: Data were extracted from the following groups of reviews based on their reporting of exercise prescription data and analysis of the relationship between prescription variables and outcomes

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: (1) those that did not report any exercise prescription data, (2) those that reported exercise prescription data but did not perform a quantitative analysis and (3) those that performed a quantitative analysis of the relationship between exercise prescription variables and outcomes.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: 6.6% of reviews did not report any exercise prescription data, and only 10.9% quantitatively analyzed the relationship between prescription variables and the outcome(s).

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: Conclusion: High methodological quality evidence is lacking for optimal exercise training prescription variables in individuals with musculoskeletal pain.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: To better inform practice and evidence gaps, future systematic reviews should (1) identify optimum exercise prescription variables, for example, via dose-response (network) meta-analysis, (2) perform high-quality reviews per AMSTAR-2 criteria and (3) include outcomes of mental health, adverse events and exercise adherence.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: The results are reverse scaled and negative values indicate an improvement with exercise interventions.

target_name: PMID: 38093145 PMCID: PMC10978700 DOI: 10.1007/s40279-023-01966-2 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract Background: Musculoskeletal pain conditions are the largest contributors to disability and healthcare burden globally.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: Objective: We aimed to examine evidence gaps, methodological quality and exercise prescription recommendations in systematic reviews of exercise for musculoskeletal pain.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: Methods: In our prospectively registered umbrella review, PubMed, SPORTDiscus, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, EMBASE, and CINAHL were searched from inception to 14 February 2023.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: We included peer-reviewed, English language, systematic reviews and meta-analyses of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and controlled clinical trials (CCTs) that compared exercise with conservative treatment, placebo or other exercise interventions in adults with musculoskeletal pain.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: AMSTAR-2 (A MeaSurement Tool to Assess systematic Reviews) was used to assess methodological quality.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: Results: From 6757 records, 274 systematic reviews were included.

source_title: The Impact of Exercise Prescription Variables on Intervention Outcomes in Musculoskeletal Pain: An Umbrella Review of Systematic Reviews
target_name: To better inform practice and evidence gaps, future systematic reviews should (1) identify optimum exercise prescription variables, for example, via dose-response (network) meta-analysis, (2) perform high-quality reviews per AMSTAR-2 criteria and (3) include outcomes of mental health, adverse events and exercise adherence.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: We collected information from studies to compare the effects of 20 exercise interventions on patients with chronic low back pain.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Network meta-analysis results showed that tai chi [standardized mean difference (SMD), -2.11; 95% CI, -3.62 to -0.61], yoga (SMD, -1.76; 95% CI -2.72 to -0.81), Pilates exercise (SMD, -1.52; 95% CI, -2.68, to -0.36), and sling exercise (SMD, -1.19; 95% CI, -2.07 to -0.30) showed a better pain improvement than conventional rehabilitation.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Yoga (SMD, -1.72; 95% CI, -2.91 to -0.53) and core or stabilization exercises (SMD, -1.04; 95% CI, -1.80 to -0.28) showed a better physical function improvement than conventional rehabilitation.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Yoga (SMD, -1.81; 95% CI, -2.78 to -0.83) and core or stabilization exercises (SMD, -1.13; 95% CI, -1.66 to -0.59) showed a better physical function improvement than no intervention provided.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Conclusion: Compared with conventional rehabilitation and no intervention provided, tai chi, toga, Pilates exercise, sling exercise, motor control exercise, and core or stabilization exercises significantly improved CLBP in patients.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Compared with conventional rehabilitation and no intervention provided, yoga and core or stabilization exercises were statistically significant in improving physical function in patients with CLBP.

target_name: Methods: We searched PubMed, EMBASE, Cochrane Library, and Web of Science from inception to 10 May 2022.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: We collected information from studies to compare the effects of 20 exercise interventions on patients with chronic low back pain.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Results: This study included 75 randomized controlled trials (RCTs) with 5,254 participants.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Network meta-analysis results showed that tai chi [standardized mean difference (SMD), -2.11; 95% CI, -3.62 to -0.61], yoga (SMD, -1.76; 95% CI -2.72 to -0.81), Pilates exercise (SMD, -1.52; 95% CI, -2.68, to -0.36), and sling exercise (SMD, -1.19; 95% CI, -2.07 to -0.30) showed a better pain improvement than conventional rehabilitation.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Tai chi (SMD, -2.42; 95% CI, -3.81 to -1.03) and yoga (SMD, -2.07; 95% CI, -2.80 to -1.34) showed a better pain improvement than no intervention provided.

source_title: Exercise intervention for patients with chronic low back pain: a systematic review and network meta-analysis
target_name: Conclusion: Compared with conventional rehabilitation and no intervention provided, tai chi, toga, Pilates exercise, sling exercise, motor control exercise, and core or stabilization exercises significantly improved CLBP in patients.

source_title: Physical therapies after surgery for lumbar disc herniation
target_name: PMID: 40165991 PMCID: PMC11957587 DOI: 10.1016/j.bas.2025.104238 Item in Clipboard Full text links Cite Display options Display options Format Abstract PubMed PMID Abstract Introduction: The role of physical therapy after lumbar disc herniation surgery is unclear.

source_title: Physical therapies after surgery for lumbar disc herniation
target_name: We demonstrated that physical therapy after lumbar disc surgery is effective in alleviating pain and improving function and quality of life after surgery for lumbar disc herniation.

source_title: Physical therapies after surgery for lumbar disc herniation
target_name: Exercise regimens aimed at enhancing the endurance, flexibility, and strength of the back musculature are generally efficacious, with the exception of exercises involving neural mobilization.

source_title: Physical therapies after surgery for lumbar disc herniation
target_name: Imposing limitations on physical activity does not yield substantial advantages; however, the occurrence rate of potential complications, the optimal timing for initiating activity and the cost-effectiveness of supervised exercise remain subjects of ongoing discourse.

source_title: Physical therapies after surgery for lumbar disc herniation
target_name: Concurrent application of manual therapy, acupuncture, educational interventions, and behavioral and occupational therapy has the potential to augment outcomes.

source_title: Physical therapies after surgery for lumbar disc herniation
target_name: Discussion and conclusion: Physical therapy improves functional outcomes after lumbar disc surgery.

target_name: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease - PMC Skip to main content An official website of the United States government Here's how you know Here's how you know Official websites use .gov A .gov website belongs to an official government organization in the United States.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Published by John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. PMC Copyright notice PMCID: PMC7120224 PMID: 24018704 This article is an update of " Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Physiotherapy aims to maximise functional ability and minimise secondary complications through movement rehabilitation within a context of education and support for the whole person.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Objectives To assess the effectiveness of physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention in patients with PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Selection criteria Randomised controlled trials of physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention in patients with PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: We used standard meta‐analysis methods to assess the effectiveness of physiotherapy intervention compared with no physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Trials were classified into the following intervention comparisons: general physiotherapy, exercise, treadmill training, cueing, dance, and martial arts.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: We used tests for heterogeneity to assess for differences in treatment effect across these different physiotherapy interventions.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Compared with no intervention, physiotherapy significantly improved the gait outcomes of speed (mean difference 0.04 m/s, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.02 to 0.06, P = 0.0002)

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: functional mobility and balance outcomes of Timed Up & Go test (‐0.63 s, 95% CI ‐1.05 to ‐0.21, P = 0.003), Functional Reach Test (2.16 cm, 95% CI 0.89 to 3.43, P = 0.0008), and Berg Balance Scale (3.71 points, 95% CI 2.30 to 5.11, P < 0.00001)

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Indirect comparisons of the different physiotherapy interventions revealed no evidence that the treatment effect differed across physiotherapy interventions for any of the outcomes assessed.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Authors' conclusions Benefit for physiotherapy was found in most outcomes over the short term (i.e. < 3 months) but was significant only for speed, two‐ or six‐minute walk test, Freezing of Gait questionnaire, Timed Up & Go, Functional Reach Test, Berg Balance Scale, and clinician‐rated UPDRS.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: However, no evidence of differences in treatment effect was noted between the different types of physiotherapy interventions being used, although this was based on indirect comparisons.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: A consensus menu of 'best practice' physiotherapy is needed, as are large, well‐designed randomised controlled trials undertaken to demonstrate the longer‐term efficacy and cost‐effectiveness of 'best practice' physiotherapy in PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: A range of approaches to movement rehabilitation are used, which aim to enhance quality of life by maximising physical ability and minimising problems related to Parkinson's over the whole course of the disease.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: In these studies,a group of participants were given physiotherapy intervention and were compared with another group of participants, who did not receive physiotherapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: These trials assessed various physiotherapy interventions, so the trials were grouped according to the type of intervention being used (i.e. general physiotherapy, exercise, treadmill training, cueing, dance, or martial arts).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Improvement in all walking outcomes (except the 10‐ or 20‐metre walk test) was noted with physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Clinician‐rated disability, using the Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS), was also improved with physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: When the different physiotherapy interventions were compared, no evidence suggested that treatment effect differed across the physiotherapy interventions for any of the outcomes assessed.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This review provides evidence of the short‐term benefit of physiotherapy for the treatment of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Although disability can occur at all stages of the disease ( Deane 2001a ), PD is progressive in nature, and so patients face increased difficulties with activities of daily living (ADL) ( Kwakkel 2007 ) and various aspects of mobility such as gait, transfers, balance, and posture ( Keus 2007b ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The management of PD has traditionally centred on drug therapy, with levodopa viewed as the 'gold standard' treatment ( Rascol 2002 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The physiotherapist is a member within this multidisciplinary team ( Robertson 2008 ; Rubenis 2007 ), whose purpose is to maximise functional ability and minimise secondary complications through movement rehabilitation within a context of education and support for the whole person ( Plant 2000 ; Deane 2001a ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Physiotherapy for PD focuses on transfers, posture, upper limb function, balance (and falls), gait, and physical capacity and (in)activity by using cueing strategies, cognitive movement strategies, and exercise to optimise the patient’s independence, safety, and well‐being, thereby enhancing quality of life ( Keus 2004 ; Keus 2007a ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Referral rates to physiotherapy for people with PD have historically been low ( Mutch 1986 ; Yarrow 1999 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: First, guidelines published by the National Collaborating Centre for Chronic Conditions ( Nat Collab Centre for Chronic Conditions 2006 ) recommended that physiotherapy be made available throughout all stages of the disease, raising the profile of the profession.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This has been further supported by the publication of Dutch physiotherapy guidelines (Keus 2004), which provide specific information for physiotherapists involved in the management of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Second, a substantial increase has been noted in the number of trials completed over the past decade (particularly in the last five years), offering supportive evidence for the inclusion of physiotherapy in the management of PD ( Keus 2009 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This Cochrane review assessing the effectiveness of physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention in patients with PD was first published in 2001, and included only 11 randomised controlled trials with a total of 280 participants ( Deane 2001a ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Most of the trials in the review reported a positive effect in favour of physiotherapy, but few outcome measures were statistically significant.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This, combined with the presence of methodological flaws, small sample sizes, and the possibility of publication bias, led Deane et al. to conclude that evidence was insufficient to support or refute the efficacy of physiotherapy for PD ( Deane 2001a ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Objectives To compare the effectiveness of physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention in participants with PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: To indirectly compare the different physiotherapy interventions used within the various trials.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Methods Criteria for considering studies for this review Types of studies For inclusion in the review, we considered all randomised controlled trials (including the first phase of cross‐over trials) comparing a physiotherapy intervention with no physiotherapy intervention (including placebo control).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: We included trials in which the no intervention arm used an active or credible placebo, as long as no physiotherapy was delivered to this group.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Any drug therapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Any duration of physiotherapy treatment.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Types of interventions Physiotherapy interventions aim to maximise functional ability and minimise secondary complications through movement rehabilitation within a context of education and support for the whole person.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Physiotherapy encompasses a wide range of techniques, so we were inclusive in our definition of physiotherapy interventions (including those not delivered by a physiotherapist) with trials of general physiotherapy, exercise, treadmill training, cueing, dance, and martial arts included.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Functional mobility and balance outcomes such as: Timed Up & Go (s) － measures time taken in seconds for a person to get up from a chair, walk a certain distance (usually three metres), turn around, and walk back to the chair and sit down ( Podsiadlo 1991 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Search methods for identification of studies The review is based on the Movement Disorders Group search strategy and the following more general search strategy: Physiotherapy OR physical therapy OR exercise OR rehabilitation.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: General biomedical and science electronic databases (without date limiters) including the Movement Disorders Review Group Specialized Register, The Cochrane Library , MEDLINE (1966‐2012), EMBASE (1974‐2012), CINAHL (1982‐2012), and ISI‐SCI (1981‐2012)

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Handsearching of general ( Lancet, BMJ, JAMA ) and specific journals ( Movement Disorders, Neurology, Archives of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, Clinical Rehabilitation, Physiotherapy, Physical Therapy ) from 2001 to the end of January 2012.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This included The XIII International Congress on Parkinson's Disease (1999), The International Congress of Parkinson's Disease and Movement Disorders (1990, 92, 94, 96, 98, 2000, 02, 04, 05, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 11), World Congress on Parkinson's Disease and Related Disorders (2009, 2012), and The American Academy of Neurology 51st Annual Meeting (1999).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Outcome data extracted included data on gait, functional mobility and balance, falls, clinician‐rated disability scale and patient‐rated quality of life, adverse events, compliance/withdrawals, and health economics where available.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Data synthesis We combined the results of all trials using standard meta‐analytic methods to estimate an overall effect for physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: These values were then combined using weighted mean difference methods to obtain the overall pooled estimate of the mean difference, with 95% confidence interval, for physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention (control).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: If the trial was comparing two or more physiotherapy interventions within the same classification (see subgroup analysis later) versus no intervention, then we combined the data for these physiotherapy interventions to give one comparison of physiotherapy intervention versus no intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: If the trial was comparing two or more physiotherapy interventions in different classifications versus no intervention, then we included that trial in each relevant physiotherapy intervention classification.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The primary analysis was a comparison of physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention (control) based on change from baseline to the first assessment after the treatment period (which in most cases was immediately post intervention).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Also, some trials allowed participants in the 'no intervention' arm to receive physiotherapy intervention after this point.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: So this allowed a clean comparison of physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Subgroup analysis and investigation of heterogeneity The different trials implemented various types of physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Therefore trials were divided according to the type of intervention administered: General physiotherapy versus control.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Exercise versus control.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: These tests may suggest the possible superiority of one type of intervention over another, and may provide clinicians and patients with more reliable information upon which to base decisions about therapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Results Description of studies We identified 76 randomised trials of physiotherapy intervention in PD patients.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Two three‐arm trials compared two exercise interventions with control.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: One compared exercise versus exercise and education versus control ( Klassen 2007 ), and the other compared exercise versus PD SAFEx versus control ( Sage 2009a ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The exercise interventions being compared in these studies were considered suitably similar, so we combined the data from the two exercise arms within each trial to obtain one comparison of exercise versus control.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Four other three‐arm trials contributed data to two of the different physiotherapy intervention comparisons.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Two of these were trials of cueing versus exercise versus control, which contributed to both the cueing versus control and exercise versus control comparisons ( Mak 2008 ; Thaut 1996 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Another trial was of treadmill versus general physiotherapy versus control, which contributed to both the treadmill versus control and general physiotherapy versus control comparisons ( Fisher 2008 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The last trial, which provided no analysable data, contributed information to two comparisons: general physiotherapy versus control and treadmill versus control ( Talakad 2011 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The 39 trials therefore contributed data to 44 comparisons within the six different types of physiotherapy interventions － general physiotherapy versus control (n=7), exercise versus control (n=14), treadmill versus control (n=8), cueing versus control (n=9), dance versus control (n=2), and martial arts versus control (n=4).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: General Physiotherapy versus Control The seven trials of general physiotherapy versus control involved 244 participants ( Chandler 1999 ; Ellis 2005 ; Fisher 2008 ; Homann 1998 ; Keus 2007b ; Stack 2012 ; Talakad 2011 )).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Sixty participants split between physiotherapy and treadmill categories are not included in this total as the group splits were not given ( Talakad 2011 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: One trial used Bobath training for gait and posture ( Homann 1998 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The remaining trials provided multifaceted interventions encompassing movement strategies, exercise, hands‐on techniques, education, and advice, targeting a wide range of areas including gait, balance, transfers, posture, and physical fitness.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Thus, general physiotherapy is a holistic intervention and on the whole uses a combination of techniques that do not routinely include complementary and/or alternative medicine such as acupuncture or hypnotherapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Exercise versus Control The 14 trials of exercise versus control involved 769 participants ( Allen 2010 ; Ashburn 2007 ; Boehm 2011 ; Cerri 1994 ; Goodwin 2009 ; Klassen 2007 ; Mak 2008 ; Meek 2010 ; Sage 2009a ; Schenkman 1998 ; Schilling 2008 ; Stozek 2003 ; Taheri 2011 ; Thaut 1996 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Exercise involved a variety of different activities, including strengthening and balance training, walking, falls prevention, neuromuscular facilitation, resistance exercise and aerobic training, and education and relaxation techniques.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Although sometimes multifaceted, the primary focus of these interventions was exercise delivery, and treatment was frequently categorised in this way by the trial authors.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Sixty participants split between physiotherapy and treadmill categories are not included in this total, as the group splits were not given ( Talakad 2011 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Treadmill training mainly involved participants walking on a treadmill with speed and/or incline adjustments.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Three trials used body weight‐supported treadmill training ( Fisher 2008 ; Ganesan 2010 ; Talakad 2011 ), and two trials provided gait and step training ( Kurtais 2008 ; Protas 2005 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Most trials looked at the short‐term effect of therapy by assessing participants at baseline and immediately or shortly after the physiotherapy intervention period (which ranged from two to 52 weeks).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Blinding of Assessors It would be impossible to blind participants and therapists to randomised treatment allocation in trials of physiotherapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Description of the No Intervention (Control) Group In most trials (n=34), the control group did not receive any physiotherapy treatment or intervention

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Shankar 2009 ), an active placebo was used that attempted to control for the time and attention involved in receiving physiotherapy intervention compared with no treatment.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: In 16 trials, this drug therapy was kept stable (low risk) throughout the duration of the trial, whereas seven trials allowed variation (unclear risk).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The remaining 16 trials did not describe drug therapy (unclear risk).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Effects of interventions Primary Analysis Gait Outcomes Two‐ or Six‐Minute Walk Test (m) Data on the two‐ or six‐minute walk test were available from six trials for seven comparisons within four physiotherapy interventions (exercise, treadmill, dance, and martial arts).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: A benefit of borderline significance was identified, along with a greater increase in the distance walked in two or six minutes with physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (mean difference 13.37 m, 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.55 to 26.20; P = 0.04; see Figure 4 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence of heterogeneity was found between the individual trials (P = 0.44, I 2 = 0%), nor did evidence suggest that the treatment effect differed across the four physiotherapy interventions (P = 0.19, I 2 = 37%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: 10‐ or 20‐Metre Walk Test(s) Data on the 10‐ or 20‐metre walk test were available from four trials for two physiotherapy interventions (exercise and treadmill).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence of heterogeneity between individual trials was obtained (P = 0.19, I 2 = 38%), nor did evidence indicate that the treatment effect differed across the two physiotherapy interventions (P = 0.51, I 2 = 0%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Speed (m/s) Data on speed were available from 15 trials for 19 comparisons within all six physiotherapy interventions.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: (Note: Fisher 2008 ; Hackney 2009 ; Mak 2008 ; and Thaut 1996 all contributed data to two physiotherapy comparisons.) Eight hundred fourteen participants were included in this analysis.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: A significant benefit was reported for physiotherapy, with speed increased by 4 cm/s with a physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (0.04 m/s, CI 0.02 to 0.06; P = 0.0002; see Figure 6 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence of heterogeneity was obtained between the individual trials (P = 0.55, I 2 = 0%), nor any evidence of heterogeneity found between the different types of physiotherapy intervention (P = 0.25, I 2 = 25%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Cadence (steps/min) Data on cadence were available from seven trials for nine comparisons within four physiotherapy interventions (general physiotherapy, exercise, treadmill, and cueing).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: (Note: Fisher 2008 and Thaut 1996 contributed data to two physiotherapy comparisons).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Stride Length (m) Data on stride length were available from six trials for nine comparisons within all six physiotherapy interventions.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: (Note: Fisher 2008 , Hackney 2009 , and Thaut 1996 contributed data to two physiotherapy comparisons.) Two hundred twenty‐five participants were included in this analysis.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Step Length (m) Data on step length were available from five trials for six comparisons within four physiotherapy interventions (general physiotherapy, exercise, treadmill, and cueing).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: (Note: Fisher 2008 contributed data to both the general physiotherapy and treadmill comparisons.) Three hundred eighty‐three participants were included in this analysis.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Freezing of Gait Questionnaire Data from the Freezing of Gait Questionnaire were available from four trials for three physiotherapy interventions (exercise, cueing, and dance).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: A borderline significant benefit was noted, with freezing of gait questionnaire score improved by 1.4 points with a physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (‐1.41, 95% CI ‐2.63 to ‐0.19; P = 0.02, see Figure 7 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence of heterogeneity between the individual trials was found (P = 0.74, I 2 = 0%), nor was there any evidence of heterogeneity between the different types of physiotherapy interventions (P = 0.55, I 2 = 0%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Functional Mobility and Balance Outcomes Timed Up & Go (s) Data on the Timed Up & Go test were available from nine trials for ten comparisons within four physiotherapy interventions (exercise, cueing, dance, and martial arts).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Overall, the time taken to complete the Timed Up & Go test was significantly improved (i.e. reduced) with physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (‐0.63 s, 95% CI ‐1.05 to ‐0.21; P = 0.003; see Figure 8 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No heterogeneity was observed between the individual trials (P = 0.12, I 2 = 36%), nor between the four physiotherapy interventions (P = 0.33, I 2 = 12%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Functional Reach Test (cm) Data on the Functional Reach Test were available from four trials for two physiotherapy interventions (exercise and cueing).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Functional reach was significantly improved with physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (2.16 cm, 95% CI 0.89 to 3.43; P = 0.0008, see Figure 9 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence suggested heterogeneity between the individual trials (P = 0.15, I 2 = 44%), nor did evidence indicate that the treatment effect differed across the two physiotherapy interventions (P = 0.48, I 2 = 0%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Berg Balance Scale Data on the Berg Balance Scale were available from five trials for six comparisons within four physiotherapy interventions (exercise, treadmill, dance, and martial arts).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The Berg Balance Scale was significantly better after physiotherapy intervention (3.71 points, 95% CI 2.30 to 5.11; P < 0.00001; see Figure 10 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence of heterogeneity between the individual trials was noted (P = 0.06, I 2 = 53%), nor did evidence suggest that the treatment effect differed across the four physiotherapy interventions (P = 0.47, I 2 = 0%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Activity‐Specific Balance Confidence Data on activity‐specific balance confidence were available from three trials for two physiotherapy interventions (exercise and cueing).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Falls Efficacy Scale Data on the Falls Efficacy Scale were available from four trials for four comparisons within two physiotherapy interventions (exercise and cueing).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) Total Data on the total UPDRS score were available from three trials for four comparisons within three physiotherapy interventions (general physiotherapy, exercise, and treadmill).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: (Note: Fisher 2008 contributed data to both the general physiotherapy and treadmill comparisons.) Two hundred seven participants were included in this analysis.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Overall, the UPDRS total score was significantly improved with physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (‐6.15 points, 95% CI ‐8.57 to ‐3.73; P =< 0.00001; see Figure 11 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Evidence of borderline heterogeneity was observed between the individual trials (P = 0.03, I 2 = 67%), and between the different types of physiotherapy intervention (P = 0.01, I 2 = 77%).

target_name: Open in a new tab UPDRS － total. Mental Data on the mental sub‐scale of the UPDRS were available from two trials for three comparisons within two physiotherapy interventions (general physiotherapy and treadmill).

target_name: (Note: Fisher 2008 contributed data to both the general physiotherapy and treadmill comparisons.) One hundred fifty‐seven participants were included in this analysis.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Overall, the UPDRS ADL score was significantly improved with physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (‐1.36 points, 95% CI ‐2.41 to ‐0.30; P = 0.01; see Figure 12 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence of heterogeneity was observed between the individual trials (P = 0.28, I 2 = 22%), nor was there any evidence of heterogeneity between the different types of physiotherapy intervention (P = 0.19, I 2 = 40%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Motor Data on the motor sub‐scale of the UPDRS were available from 12 trials for 14 comparisons within all six physiotherapy interventions.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: (Note: Fisher 2008 and Hackney 2009 contributed data to two physiotherapy interventions.) Five hundred ninety‐three participants were included in this analysis.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Overall, the UPDRS motor score was significantly improved with physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (‐5.01 points, CI ‐6.30 to ‐3.72; P < 0.00001; see Figure 13 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Evidence indicated significant heterogeneity between the individual trials (P = 0.0009, I 2 = 63%) and across the six physiotherapy interventions (P = 0.0001, I 2 = 80%).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: 39 (PDQ‐39) Summary Index Data on the Summary Index of the PDQ‐39 were available from seven trials for eight comparisons within all six physiotherapy interventions.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No difference between treatment arms was observed in patient‐rated quality of life after physiotherapy intervention (‐0.38 points, 95% CI ‐2.58 to 1.81; P = 0.73).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Mobility Data on the mobility domain of the PDQ‐39 were available from two trials for three comparisons within three physiotherapy interventions (general physiotherapy, dance, and martial arts).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No difference in the PDQ‐39 mobility score was observed between the two treatment arms (‐1.43, 95% CI ‐8.03 to 5.18; P = 0.67).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Discussion Summary of main results This review updates the previous Cochrane review published in 2001 ( Deane 2001a ) comparing physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention for the treatment of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: It also compares the different types of physiotherapy interventions used in the treatment of PD, thus providing a comprehensive assessment of physiotherapy treatment.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Many recent systematic reviews have focused on specific areas of physiotherapy such as exercise and cueing ( Crizzle 2006 ; Goodwin 2008 ; Lim 2005 ; Nieuwboer 2008 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Nowadays, physiotherapy for PD encompasses a wide range of methods and techniques ranging from standard NHS physiotherapy to exercise regimens and martial arts.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Therefore, it is important that all forms of physiotherapy intervention are included, so that the true benefit (if any) of physiotherapy can be assessed.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The review also includes a more comprehensive range of outcome measures compared with previous reviews (18 outcomes assessing gait, functional mobility and balance, falls, clinician‐rated Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS), and patient‐rated quality of life), thus providing the most reliable summary available of the current published evidence.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Physiotherapy Intervention versus No Physiotherapy Intervention This review provides evidence of the short‐term (< three months) benefit of physiotherapy in the treatment of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: All outcomes showed improvement with physiotherapy intervention compared with no intervention (except the 10‐ or 20‐metre walk test).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: However, significant benefits after physiotherapy intervention were observed only for the gait outcomes of speed, the two‐ or six‐minute walk test, and the Freezing of Gait questionnaire; the functional and mobility outcomes of the Timed Up & Go test, Functional Reach Test, and Berg Balance Scale; and the clinician‐rated UPDRS.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: It is of interest that the direction of the treatment effect favoured physiotherapy intervention in all outcome measures, except one.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The absence of evidence in these outcomes is not necessarily evidence of the absence of benefit for physiotherapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Gait People with PD frequently have problems with gait, and treatment is usually targeted toward maximising exercise tolerance, improving the gait pattern, maintaining or increasing independence regarding mobility, and reducing the risk of falls.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Freezing of gait is a prevalent motor disturbance within PD, and it is known to have a detrimental impact on quality of life, as well as on gait and mobility ( Moore 2007 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Speed was significantly improved with physiotherapy intervention by 0.04 metres/s.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: For the two‐ or six‐minute walk test and freezing of gait, participants who received physiotherapy intervention were able to walk further over two or six minutes (by 13 m) and their Freezing of Gait score was improved by 1.4 points.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Functional Mobility and Balance Changes in functional mobility and balance within PD have been well documented ( Bloem 2001 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Of the functional mobility and balance outcomes assessed within this review, significant improvements were observed in the Timed Up & Go test, Functional Reach Test, and Berg Balance Scale.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The time taken to complete the Timed Up & Go test was significantly improved by 0.63 seconds with physiotherapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Therefore, the small change observed within this review may not translate into a noticeable improvement in a person’s functional mobility.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: In this review, a significant four‐point improvement in the Berg Balance Scale was noted after physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: In turn, it could be hypothesised that improvement in balance does not directly equate to improved levels of mobility and independence.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Although fear of falling was not reduced with physiotherapy within this review, it would be of interest to assess whether the number of falls was reduced, as this may be more relevant to patients.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This suggests that physiotherapy intervention is beneficial in improving motor symptoms and may positively impact ADL.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Patient‐Rated Quality of Life No significant benefit of physiotherapy intervention for overall patient‐rated quality of life (measured using the Parkinson’s Disease Questionnaire (PDQ)‐39 Summary Index) or the mobility domain of the PDQ‐39 was noted, which is surprising in light of the significant improvements seen in UPDRS scores.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Another study ( Chandler 1999 ) assessed patient quality of life using the generic Short Form‐36 and also showed no effect of physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Comparison of Different Physiotherapy Interventions Although we found short‐term benefit for physiotherapy intervention in the treatment of PD, what is less clear is whether a certain type of physiotherapy intervention may provide greater benefit.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This information would be of interest to both clinicians and patients, so that appropriate physiotherapy interventions that provide greater benefit can be delivered to patients with PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: To assess this, we categorised the various physiotherapy interventions used in the trials included in this review according to the type of treatment administered, and then compared them using tests for heterogeneity.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: We found no real evidence of any differences in the treatment effect between the different physiotherapy interventions used for any of the outcomes assessed.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: However, these were based on indirect comparisons (with limited data within each physiotherapy intervention) so should be interpreted with caution.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: They would be better assessed in trials directly comparing different types of physiotherapy interventions.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This lack of difference between the different types of physiotherapy intervention is perhaps not surprising.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: By nature physiotherapists are autonomous professionals with differing sets of skills who work within their own scope of practice ( Chartered Society of Physiotherapy ), and so this variation in the interventions delivered within clinical trials may actually reflect clinical practice.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Over the past decade, steps have been taken to try to provide best practice consensus in the form of the Dutch KNGF guidelines for physical therapy in patients with Parkinson’s disease ( Keus 2004 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: It is therefore important that physiotherapy interventions are compared against each other within rigorous trial designs to determine which are most effective.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The need for further improvement in the methodological quality of trials in physiotherapy for PD was noted in another recent systematic review ( Kwakkel 2007 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The trials included in the review were relatively small, with most assessing the effects of physiotherapy intervention versus no physiotherapy intervention over a short period with limited follow‐up.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: To highlight this point, this review illustrates that any differences observed in the various outcome measures showing benefit for physiotherapy were quite small.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Thus, this review is able to provide conclusions only on the short‐term benefits of physiotherapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: It is also important to consider results alongside the possibility of a so‐called honeymoon effect ( Goetz 2008 ) in the period during or just after physiotherapy, which may inflate the treatment effect in favour of physiotherapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Long‐term data will provide valuable information about the duration of any improvement following therapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The outcome measures included in this review are standard physiotherapy and PD outcomes.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Further, no health economics analysis of physiotherapy intervention was reported; therefore little is known about the cost‐effectiveness and economic value of this therapy.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: In summary, this review provides evidence of the short‐term (< three months) benefit of physiotherapy intervention for the treatment of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: To clarify the long‐term (if any) benefit of physiotherapy, additional large, well‐designed randomised trials with a follow‐up of at least 12 months, alongside a health economics assessment, are needed to assess the impact of this treatment on all aspects of a patient's PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Authors' conclusions Implications for practice.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Physiotherapy provides short‐term benefit in the treatment of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Significant benefits with physiotherapy intervention were observed for the following outcomes: two‐ or six‐minute walk test, speed, Freezing of Gait questionnaire, Timed Up & Go test, Functional Reach Test, Berg Balance Scale, and UPDRS total, ADL, and motor scores.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The long‐term, if any, benefit of physiotherapy remains unidentified, as does which type of physiotherapy intervention should be delivered.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Therefore, although this review has provided evidence that physiotherapy intervention may be of benefit to PD patients, it has also highlighted that further evidence is needed before firm conclusions can be made on the long‐term benefit and on which physiotherapy intervention should be used.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Additionally, only one trial looked at the longer‐term benefit of physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: To assess whether, or how long, any improvements due to physiotherapy intervention may last, it is important that long‐term follow‐up is performed.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: No evidence indicates the best form of physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Comparisons of the different physiotherapy interventions described in this review were based on indirect comparisons between individual trials.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: A more reliable comparison would be obtained in large, randomised trials that directly compare different physiotherapy interventions.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This review highlights the variety of physiotherapy interventions being used in the treatment of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: More specific trials with improved treatment strategies are needed to underpin the most appropriate choice of physiotherapy intervention and the outcomes measured.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Authors' conclusions Benefit for physiotherapy was found in most outcomes over the short term (i.e. < 3 months) but was significant only for speed, two‐ or six‐minute walk test, Freezing of Gait questionnaire, Timed Up & Go, Functional Reach Test, Berg Balance Scale, and clinician‐rated UPDRS.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: These benefits should be interpreted with caution because the quality of most of the included trials was not high.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: A range of approaches to movement rehabilitation are used, which aim to enhance quality of life by maximising physical ability and minimising problems related to Parkinson's over the whole course of the disease.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Improvement in all walking outcomes (except the 10‐ or 20‐metre walk test) was noted with physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: However, these improvements were significant only for walking speed, walking endurance, and freezing of gait.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Clinician‐rated disability, using the Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS), was also improved with physiotherapy intervention.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: This review provides evidence of the short‐term benefit of physiotherapy for the treatment of PD.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Although most observed differences were small, improvements in walking speed, balance with the Berg Balance Scale, and clinician‐rated disability using the UPDRS were of a size that patients may consider them to be important.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: These benefits should be interpreted with caution because of the quality of the included trials, and the lack of common assessment of treatment effects.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Although disability can occur at all stages of the disease ( Deane 2001a ), PD is progressive in nature, and so patients face increased difficulties with activities of daily living (ADL) ( Kwakkel 2007 ) and various aspects of mobility such as gait, transfers, balance, and posture ( Keus 2007b ).

target_name: Ultimately, this leads to decreased independence, inactivity, and social isolation ( Keus 2007b ), resulting in reduced quality of life ( Schrag 2000 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Although disability can occur at all stages of the disease ( Deane 2001a ), PD is progressive in nature, and so patients face increased difficulties with activities of daily living (ADL) ( Kwakkel 2007 ) and various aspects of mobility such as gait, transfers, balance, and posture ( Keus 2007b ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: However, even with optimal medical management, patients with PD experience deterioration in body function, daily activities, and participation ( Nijkrake 2007 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: The physiotherapist is a member within this multidisciplinary team ( Robertson 2008 ; Rubenis 2007 ), whose purpose is to maximise functional ability and minimise secondary complications through movement rehabilitation within a context of education and support for the whole person ( Plant 2000 ; Deane 2001a ).

target_name: However, in recent years, the number of referrals has increased, with a survey by Parkinson’s UK in 2008 reporting that 54% of the 13,000 members surveyed had seen a physiotherapist compared with 27% in a survey undertaken in 1998 ( PDS 2008 ; Yarrow 1999 ).

target_name: Second, a substantial increase has been noted in the number of trials completed over the past decade (particularly in the last five years), offering supportive evidence for the inclusion of physiotherapy in the management of PD ( Keus 2009 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Types of outcome measures Gait outcomes such as: Two‐ or six‐minute walk test (m) － measures the number of metres a person can walk in two or six minutes, thereby providing a measurement of walking endurance ( Kersten 2004 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Walking speed 10‐ or 20‐metre walk test (s) － measures the time in seconds that a person takes to walk 10 or 20 metres, thereby providing a measurement of gait speed ( Kersten 2004 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Speed (m/s) － measures the rate of change of position, recorded in metres per second ( Trew 2005 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Cadence (steps/min) － measures the number of steps taken in a given period, which is then converted into the number of steps taken per minute ( Trew 2005 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Functional mobility and balance outcomes such as: Timed Up & Go (s) － measures time taken in seconds for a person to get up from a chair, walk a certain distance (usually three metres), turn around, and walk back to the chair and sit down ( Podsiadlo 1991 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Activity Specific Balance Confidence － 16‐item self‐report questionnaire that asks individuals to rate their confidence that they will maintain their balance in the course of daily activities.

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Falls Efficacy Scale － 10‐item patient‐reported questionnaire that measures how confident a person is at carrying out various activities of daily living (ADL).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Columbia University Rating Scale － assessment of motor impairment and activities of daily living against 13 items, using a five‐point scale for each to yield a total score between 0=normal and 65=maximum disability ( Yahr 1969 ).

source_title: Physiotherapy versus placebo or no intervention in Parkinson's disease
target_name: Effects of interventions Primary Analysis Gait Outcomes Two‐ or Six‐Minute Walk Test (m) Data on the two‐ or six‐minute walk test were available from six trials for seven comparisons within four physiotherapy interventions (exercise, treadmill, dance, and martial arts).
