target_name: Stroke results in imbalance which decreases activity, autonomy and quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Purpose: To determine the efficacy of PT on the recovery of balance and postural control in adult patients after stroke.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: All randomised controlled trials investigating the efficacy of PT on balance and postural control in adult patients after stroke (18 years or above) without language restriction were included.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Primary outcomes were balance (measured by the Berg Balance Scale or the Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke), postural deviation (measured by the weight bearing on limbs or the position of the centre of pressure (COP) during static assessment) and postural stability (measured by all COP sway or limit of stability parameters during sitting or standing static assessment).

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Conclusion(s): PT was helpful to improve balance, to decrease postural asymmetry and to improve postural stability, with an expansion of these effects to autonomy, in stroke patients immediately after intervention.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Implications: PT can be used to recover balance and postural control after stroke.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Methods: A systematic review and meta-analysis were performed according to the Cochrane and PRISMA recommendations (Hugues et al., 2017).

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Primary outcomes were balance (measured by the Berg Balance Scale or the Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke), postural deviation (measured by the weight bearing on limbs or the position of the centre of pressure (COP) during static assessment) and postural stability (measured by all COP sway or limit of stability parameters during sitting or standing static assessment).

target_name: Stroke results in imbalance which decreases activity, autonomy and quality of life.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Purpose: To determine the efficacy of PT on the recovery of balance and postural control in adult patients after stroke.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Medline, Embase, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, PEDro, Pascal and Francis databases were searched from inception until 31 October 2015.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: All randomised controlled trials investigating the efficacy of PT on balance and postural control in adult patients after stroke (18 years or above) without language restriction were included.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Primary outcomes were balance (measured by the Berg Balance Scale or the Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke), postural deviation (measured by the weight bearing on limbs or the position of the centre of pressure (COP) during static assessment) and postural stability (measured by all COP sway or limit of stability parameters during sitting or standing static assessment).

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: PT was more effective than no treatment for the short-term recovery of balance (standardized mean difference 0.48, 95% confidence interval [0.36, 0.59]), mediolateral postural deviation with eyes open (EO) (-0.27, [-0.42, -0.13]) and postural stability EO (0.31, [0.06, 0.57]), with an expansion to autonomy (0.36, [0.21, 0.51]).

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: PT was more effective than sham treatment or usual care for the short-term recovery of balance (0.30, [0.11, 0.48]), mediolateral postural deviation EO (-0.59, [-1.08, -0.09]) and postural stability (EO: 0.91, [0.34, 1.48]; EC: 0.98, [0.35, 1.62]), with an expansion to autonomy (0.43, [0.07, 0.80]).

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: The quality of short-term effects was judged as moderate for balance and low to moderate for postural control by the grades of recommendation, assessment, development, and evaluations from Cochrane.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Conclusion(s): PT was helpful to improve balance, to decrease postural asymmetry and to improve postural stability, with an expansion of these effects to autonomy, in stroke patients immediately after intervention.

source_title: Physical Therapy is Beneficial for the Recovery of Balance and Postural Control in Stroke Patients: a systematic review and meta analysis
target_name: Implications: PT can be used to recover balance and postural control after stroke.

target_name: Discussion The evidence regarding the benefits and harms of education/advice for CPLBP in adults is based on 15 RCTs (16 reports) (n = 1403 total adults, n = 60 older adults).

target_name: Compared to no intervention (including comparison interventions where the attributable effect of education/advice could be isolated), evidence suggested that education/advice is associated with a reduction in depression and improvement in self-efficacy immediately post-intervention.

target_name: Conclusion Based on very low certainty evidence, education/advice in adults with CPLBP was associated with improvements in pain, function, HRQoL and psychological outcomes compared to no intervention (including interventions where the attributable effect of education/advice could be isolated), or usual care.

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: Acupuncture Back Pain Chiropractic Medicine Pain management Physiotherapy Quality of Life Research The World Health Organization (WHO) is developing a clinical practice guideline for the management of chronic primary low back pain (CPLBP) in adults, including older adults aged 60 years and older.

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: To inform the development of WHO clinical practice recommendations, we updated four systematic reviews assessing four common interventions used in the treatment of CPLBP that were previously published in 2021 (education/advice [ 1 ] and exercise [ 2 ]), 2008 (transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation [TENS]) [ 3 ], and 2020 (needling therapies) [ 4 ].

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: (1) the benefits and harms (as reported in RCTs) of four interventions (structured and standardized education/advice, structured exercise programs, TENS, needling therapies) for the management of adults with CPLBP, including older adults

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: Our protocols were registered with the International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (PROSPERO): TENS (#CRD42022314817), needling therapies (#CRD42022314824), education or advice (# CRD42022314804), and exercise (#CRD42022314576).

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: Interventions The interventions are described in detail in the respective systematic reviews in this series for structured and standardized education/advice [ 11 ], structured exercise programs [ 12 ], TENS [ 13 ] and needling therapies [ 14 ].

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: Comparators We included RCTs that compared the interventions of interest to placebo/sham, usual care (i.e., standard care by a general practitioner that people would receive without being enrolled in the RCT), or no intervention (including comparison interventions where the attributable effect of the intervention could be isolated, e.g., exercise + manual therapy vs. same manual therapy alone).

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: Development of Search Strategies We searched the same electronic databases and registries as the published systematic reviews (e.g., MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trial [CENTRAL]) from the end date of the published review until 9 March 2022 (structured and standardized education/advice TENS, needling therapies,) or 17 May 2022 (structured exercise programs).

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: All screening, data extraction and risk of bias forms and guidance used in the conduct of the systematic reviews were developed, pilot-tested, and used by Hayden et al. in the conduct of ‘exercise for chronic low back pain’ collaborative review, in which members of our team participated [ 17 ].

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: As part of the collaborative review [ 17 ], members of our team received training for all stages of the exercise review (screening, data extraction, and risk of bias).

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: We provided additional internal team training for practices that varied from the exercise review protocol (e.g., extraction of data for additional outcomes) and for the other three interventions.

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: For the exercise systematic review only, we excluded from the evidence synthesis RCTs that were judged to have an overall high ROB.

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: However, the WHO commissioned a supplementary evidence synthesis from our team consisting of all eligible RCTs including those rated overall high ROB (details provided in the exercise systematic review in this series) [ 20 ] The WHO GDG used the original and supplementary evidence syntheses to inform their clinical practice recommendations.

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: The GDG considered the overall benefit of an intervention, taking into account the effect size as well as factors such as its delivery and accessibility to judge its effectiveness and suitability for use in clinical practice.

target_name: The IASP defines CPLBP, previously referred to as “non-specific LBP”, as pain that persists or recurs for longer than 3 months, is associated with emotional distress and/or functional disability, and the symptoms cannot be better accounted for by another diagnosis, such as tissue damage or a disease process [ 9 ].

target_name: For the purpose of this guideline, CPLBP was defined as pain that persists or recurs for longer than 3 months and symptoms cannot be better accounted for by another diagnosis, such as tissue damage or a disease process.

target_name: To inform the development of WHO clinical practice recommendations, we updated four systematic reviews assessing four common interventions used in the treatment of CPLBP that were previously published in 2021 (education/advice [ 1 ] and exercise [ 2 ]), 2008 (transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation [TENS]) [ 3 ], and 2020 (needling therapies) [ 4 ].

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: This report outlines the common objectives and methods used to conduct the four systematic reviews that were commissioned by the WHO [ 5 ].

target_name: We excluded RCTs with post-surgical participants with less than 12 months duration since surgery or who had been managed with fusion or disc replacement surgery at any time, pregnant participants, and individuals with a clearly determined specific cause for their LBP (chronic secondary LBP) (e.g., vertebral fracture, malignancy, inflammatory disease).

target_name: Comparators We included RCTs that compared the interventions of interest to placebo/sham, usual care (i.e., standard care by a general practitioner that people would receive without being enrolled in the RCT), or no intervention (including comparison interventions where the attributable effect of the intervention could be isolated, e.g., exercise + manual therapy vs. same manual therapy alone).

source_title: Systematic Review Procedures for the World Health Organization (WHO) Evidence Syntheses on Benefits and Harms of Structured and Standardized Education/Advice, Structured Exercise Programs, Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS), and Needling Therapies for the Management of Chronic Low Back Pain in Adults
target_name: Development of Search Strategies We searched the same electronic databases and registries as the published systematic reviews (e.g., MEDLINE, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trial [CENTRAL]) from the end date of the published review until 9 March 2022 (structured and standardized education/advice TENS, needling therapies,) or 17 May 2022 (structured exercise programs).

target_name: The IASP defines CPLBP, previously referred to as “non-specific LBP”, as pain that persists or recurs for longer than 3 months, is associated with emotional distress and/or functional disability, and the symptoms cannot be better accounted for by another diagnosis, such as tissue damage or a disease process [ 9 ].
